author: Alicia M.

description:
Crepe-tastic

Very very good casual breakfast near Union Square. 

I'd recommend the Miami Heat Crepe (avocado, chicken breast, cheddar, etc). I was unsure but it was fantastic. Going again before leaving town.
author: Millard M.

description:
Food:  The crepes were very small and they seemed to skimp on the fillings.  The omelet I had was okay, definitely could make it better in my own home.  I also had a peek into the kitchen and saw fresh strawberries being prepared no more and than a couple of feet away from a bowl of raw meat on the same table.  Not sure if this is a health code violation or not but it just seemed a little close for comfort.
 
Service:  I took 3 kids and two adults to this place on a busy Saturday based on the great Yelp reviews however, after ordering and waiting 30 minutes for our food it turned out that they lot our order ticket and we had to re-order our food.  They did comp us our meal.  Also when arriving into the cafe, there is an unspoken rule apparently that you are to order your food BEFORE you find a place to sit however they had no-one to assist customers on that busy Saturday as the line stretched out of the door; My party and I witnessed a nasty argument between two customers over seating.

Bottom line:  I can always let service "fluke" go by, every business has good days and bad days but as far as the food goes, it was sub-par and would have rather taken my party to Sears Fine Foods near Union Square.
author: Mark D.

description: This a great three and a half star breakfast joint. I ordered the egg/ham croissant, a baklava crepe, and an orange juice. The croissant was good, a tad too doughy but good nonetheless, and seemingly made in house. The baklava crepe was delicious, but how could a baklava crepe not be? And the bump in a half star, since I have to choose to inflate or deflate my rating due to the lack of half stars *shakes fist at the Yelp gods*, is for the orange juice. I Love fresh squeezed orange juice.
author: Mark S.

description: This restaurant is in a really great area on a perfect corner in the heart of the city. My eggs were good, but pretty basic and the fruit wasn't the freshest. The French toast and sourdough bread were really delicious. The atmosphere is a little odd, since it's very spaced out and painted a weird leafy pattern that makes you think ancient Italy. I think the place is good, if you're looking for a quick bite to eat. Next time I think I'll try a crepe!
author: Abby S.

description: Excellent service, great food, low prices for high quality dishes. I always get the Union Square Burger (add avocado) with curly fries. Can't be beat in this touristy area. Great crepe and breakfast options as well.
author: Jonathan R.

description: It's a cute place, but the service is terrible and the food isn't much better. The cashier just took my order and walked out without a word whilst I was trying to pay her. During most of my time here the tables remained dirty for a substantial time after visitors had left. The food was edible but not worth the ambitious price tag.
author: Andrea F.

description: Awesome place. Great food. Nice vibe. Amazing crepes. Delicious cappuccinos! Definitely recommend!
author: Vivian H.

description: Line is out the door, so be prepared to wait 45 minutes outside. First time we went, food was good. Second time, disappointed in the fact that the omelettes were half the size. Coffee could be better. The latte is seriously lacking--it was more like steamed milk with a little bit of coffee poured in. My boyfriend also ordered a crepe and agreed that his order was smaller than what he'd had just two days before. I had a good experience here the first time I went but I don't think the long line is worth going through for such an inconsistent dining experience.
author: Marie S.

description: Love this place!  Food was fantastic!  Also really like the fact that the restaurant is family owned and managed. The family sees that customers are served promptly and ensures that that the food is perfectly prepared and delivered to the tables as soon as it hits the plate. For those in the area, this is the place to have breakfast or brunch. Look no further.
author: Kerry M.

description:
This place is so good that we had to make a 2nd trip there before leaving San Fran!

First visit - The pesto crepe is AMAZING!  Fresh, delicious and oh so tasty! The North Beach crepe with the hollandaise sauce was heavenly!  Very filling and everything worked magically in the crepe!

Second visit - The breakfast crepe was equally good and satisfying.  The 2-2-2 breakfast with pancakes, bacon and eggs (and yes they do substitute with egg whites if you ask) hit the spot perfectly!

Overall, fantastic food, quick and friendly service, fresh ingredients and a great location!
author: Ragini S.

description:
Honey Honey was so good my boyfriend & I went twice during our stay in San Francisco. The first time we went for breakfast. I ordered the breakfast crepe with bacon no ham, cheddar cheese, bell peppers, eggs, and onions. A mix of an omelet but with the sweet taste of a crepe...so good! It comes with a side of potatoes...some of the best potatoes I have had. Nicely cooked with a bit of crunch. My boyfriend ordered the chicken pesto crepe. Go ahead make a face but damn was it good. It had swiss cheese, tomatoes, garlic, fresh basil, and chicken breast of course. Sounds weird for breakfast but it was so tasty. It came with potatoes as well. 

On our second visit I couldn't decide what to order since they have such a selection of food that sounds good. Since I hardly eat crepes and this was our last day in town, I decided to go with another crepe plate. I had the North Beach crepe. Swiss cheese, onion, mushrooms, spinach, chicken breast topped with a hollandaise sauce/cream, and of course with their potatoes. Yes, I remembered all this haha. I liked that it had a different flavor to it kind of spicy but not to overwhelming went well with the crepe. 

They have so much more than just crepes, I wish I would have tried their sweet, fruity crepes but I was to full. They have a sandwiches, waffles, burrito, etc.  A great place for breakfast, lunch or dinner.  Good customer service.  Clean establishment.  They do get pretty busy but they are fast, just have some patience.  I really enjoyed their coffee and mimosa. They actually have a couple of beers on tap. Good prices for the amount of food and quality/taste of the food.  It all tasted so fresh.  If you are in the area I highly recommend it.
author: Marlene M.

description:
I'm gonna go 4 stars on this one...

The food was pretty dang good.  I had the Cancun burger with Fries.  The Fries were piping hot!  That is huge points in my book.  If the fries are hot it tells me that EITHER you believe it cooking to order... OR you are so slammed that you are racing to catch up.  Since my order did not take that long I am going to go with the fresh focus.

My friend ordered the Apple Turkey Sandwich.  She was pleasantly surprised to find actual apples and slice turkey.  She figured it would be some type of turkey salad with apple chunks.  She had fresh fruit on the side that was a good mix of fresh items and not your standard fare.  I HATE it when restaurants advertise 'Fresh Fruit' and you get a dish of honeydew... SERIOUSLY??? But that wasn't the case here.

My only issues with the place was the service wasn't phenomenal.  It wasn't horrible either, but with a little effort they could go a lot further.  Also the booths are too tall for the tables.  I am a short dude and I hit my knee a couple times.

All in all it was a good food experience and if you are in the area I recommend hitting it up!
author: Gabe H.

description:
Super close to our hotel when we stayed in Union Square. We ate here twice - breakfast and dinner.

The eggs benedict is good, but a bit spicy.  The staff was nice - nothing noteworthy, but certainly not bad.

My daughter spilled water, and someone came right over and cleaned it up for us, and was quite nice and not at all put out.

Also - the crepes are awesome.  G
author: Penny G.

description: went in and split the north beach crepe and the dulce crepe with a friend. north beach was really filling, stuffed with spinach and mushrooms and chicken, i typically don't like cheese but this had it perfectly melted. it was served hot with a side of potatoes and salad.  after that i had the dulce crepe, with caramelized pecans as a filling and topped with chopped pecans, chocolate and caramel drizzle and powdered sugar. served with aside of vanilla bean ice cream. other than the dishes that i tried, i appreciated the range of sweet and savory crepes they had (especially the sweet ones, because it was more than just nutella+ bananas/strawberries) overall definitely worth the price, and super delicious food. also was great that the guy serving us was really nice about everything. if you're in the area, check this place out~
author: Kim C.

description: Most delicious meal ever!!  Great cider, coffee and such a huge variety of food to choose from. Crowded but you get seated easily. Price isn't too bad either!
author: Mrs. R.

description: The best thing about this place is the name. Other than that's it's just average. They have a huge menu but nothing on it is very exciting. I got a savory crepe and my friend got the Benedict and both were not bad, but not amazing either. The one bonus is that this place has free wifi.
author: Laura K.

description:
I don't get to eat blintzes very often - it's not the most common breakfast food a person sees in STL. So I was excited to try one at Honey Honey. And it lived up to my expectations! 

Strawberry preserves and orange marmalade wrapped up in a nice little crepe. Yum! That and a side of bacon and I'm in a tiny food coma.

We unfortunately sat by some really loud ladies who insisted on reading the Olympics edition of Parade Magazine out-lout. It's not that I don't care about the athletes to watch, but did she have to yell? 

Either way, the food at Honey Honey was delicious. Next time I'll sit in a quiet corner :)
author: Abby S.

description: I found this on yelp and was looking forward to it. I love brunch, it is my favorite meal of the day. Even trekked 15 mins from the muni exit to get here. My philosophy on restaurants is the lengthier the menu, the worse it taste and sadly this place confirms it. I ordered what I thought is an easy to do "breakfast savory crepe" but like the usual American cooking, they stacked it with mounds of cheese and piled on your plate with a lot of food. Quantity doesn't mean quality. And sometimes less is definitely best, especially in this case where all I tasted was a whole lot of cheese. The potatoes were overcooked making it really dry and not properly seasoned. I think the lack of attention to proportions of ingredients and basic seasoning, i will sadly give them 3 stars.
author: Sandy P.

description:
Came here solo on a Saturday morning around 7:45am. There was a line but plenty of seating still. 
I ordered the crab cake Benedict and a mimosa. 
The eggs in the Benedict were over cooked, the yolks were almost completely solid. The hollandaise sauce was pretty tasty but the spinach tasted funny. The potatoes were cooked well and were flavorful.  My mimosa was also strange, it tasted fine, but had an orange powdery film on top. 
I'll probably come back to try the dessert crepes, but if I want to pay that much for breakfast again, I'll go to Nob Hill Grill for their brunch. Way better food at similar price.
author: Tina M.

description:
Any place with fresh squeezed orange juice can be my friend. 

Pesto crepes, amazing bacon, and fantastic ginger tea rounded out my brunch. The Bollywood-style music was a bit random but worked pretty well actually. I'd love to come again.
author: Nathaniel J.

description:
Long wait time at lunch. With an unfocused menu (pasta, burgers, crepes, salads, sandwiches, beer, wine, coffee, tea, italian sodas, and so on), you don't expect them to do anything extremely well; unfortunately, they never exceeded this expectation. 

Crepevine that this place is frequently compared to serves much better crepes. Haven't tried anything else here besides the crepes, so I can't comment on any other dishes.
author: Gleb P.

description: Wonderful strawberry nutella creape with apple sausage! Nice local spot for breakfast.
author: Virginia M.

description: After running a very long race around San Fran, I was desperately in need of food and a mimosa. A hungry bus full of sweaty women was let off in front of Honey Honey, making it the best restaurant in San Francisco at that moment. Thankfully, mimosas and Bloody Mary's are served here, making it an even better choice. I kept it simple with a burger, fries, and mimosa; my friend got some nice looking and tasting crepes and a drink as well. The rest of the menu was fairly extensive and by the time we finished, the line was out the door. Would love to come back for some more crepes!
author: Heather M.

description:
We fell in love with this place after trying it due to the convenient location near our hotel. We wanted to try other places that trip and after a terrible experience at a near by diner (long wait for a you-get-what-you-pay-for sad excuse for a breakfast place), we went right back to HH. 

We go to HH every time we are in SF. The food, no matter what we have ordered, (crepes, eggs and hash browns, eggs Benedict, pancakes, oatmeal, granola, croissant  sandwich, and French toast to name a few), has come out consistently delicious. 

The service is timely, the prices are accurate for the type of food you are getting (which is freshly made from classic recipes to a unique twist), and the menu has enough variety without going over the top (like those "we have Mexican, American, Chinese, Italian, and Jamaican on our menu" places).

There are times when the line is out the door. I've never seen anyone holding their food and looking for a table though, and as a growing family (from newly weds to three, and now four), we have always found seats. Sure, you are aware the staff's stress level, but whether there is one person at the cash register who is also in charge of making drinks and getting the food out, or three people, the timing of service has stayed the same!
author: Jace M.

description: I went there for breakfast and ordered an eggplant crepe (tasted like a wet cheese burrito) They messed up my order and said I had ordered something else. He didn't believe me and said he had to check his receipt (what?) He finally came back with the crepe I wanted but it did not come with a side of fruit like i had asked...bad first experience. My husband's fruit crepe with ice cream was pretty delicious but it wasn't served with a spoon. This was not worth the wait.
author: Mary R.

description: Quick service, good selection. If you like crepes, you'll appreciate theirs. Their crab cakes Benedict is also good and extremely filling.
author: Rose P.

description:
A staple.

I love Brunch, but I hate the lines.  This place, although the line can be daunting on the weekends, by the time you get through it, grab a seat, boom! your food is ready.

The menu is expansive, and there is a little bit of something for everyone.

- Chorizo Omelet:  This technically is a "scramble," but I always order it in an omelet form, because it just looks plain gross as a scramble. It's got fabulous flavor, and just is a nice take to an omelet with some spice to it.
- California Sandwich: There's avo on it. How very california.  Its a nice sammy with a delish, and fresh take to it
- Banana Pecan Pancakes: When on the special board, get it! It's utterly decadent.  But have your fellow diner get something savory and split it.  Perfection.

All in all. I love the beat of this place. But it's a quick eat and go.  Not a place to camp out with a computer and mellow out.  Head to a real coffee shop, this is a place of in and out service. :)
author: Natalie G.

description: The crepes were amazing! The eggs Benedict was good. It was a little cramped but worth it because of the crepes! Can't wait to go back!
author: Melissa H.

description: The menu is overflowing with good choices. There's something for everyone! It's also easy to split the bill since you order first, then sit. The orange juice is excellent as is the chicken apple sausage! It's also not nearly as crowded as some of the other "top" breakfast places but just as good or better.
author: Chris S.

description: Good quality breakfast and a varied menu. We experienced a 30 minute line on a Monday morning albeit Christmas week. Definitely worth a stop if you have the time or find no line.
author: Jeff N.

description:
Sloppy seconds.

Such a good first visit. Such a disappointing second visit.

Presentation.

Granola and select pieces of fruit were drowning in milk. Needed a better balance. Also needed a better job cutting the apple and banana slices. Too big to be scooped up with the granola. Made for some awkward table manners.

Accounting.

Peanut butter, rice krispie and marshmallow crêpe was a highlight. Too bad the $5.95 price on the specials board rang up as $6.25 on the register. End of the world? No. Any attempt to refund the difference or apologize? No. 

Connection.

One of the worst WiFi connections I've encountered in an establishment that touts free WiFi. Slow and erratic.

Third time won't be the charm as there won't be a third time.
author: Jason B.

description: This place was a walk from the hotel that I was staying at when I was visiting San Fran. The place is very cute and the food taste  delicious! I had the strawberry desert crepes for breakfast and it was made with fresh strawberries . Just awesome !
author: Emily H.

description:
There are a a ton of creperies around the city...crepe house, crepevine, crepes a go go, genki crepes...Honey Honey compared to its peers was a little below par both in terms of quality and value.  Many of the usual options were offered, sweet and savory crepes, sandwiches, soups, salads, etc.  However unlike other crepe houses where they give you salad AND another option of potatoes or fruit Honey Honey only gives you one option (salad or potatos or fruit).   The vegetarian chili was cold and the bread they served with it was stale. bleh.

If I ever do make it back there I would stick with the dessert crepes. It's pretty hard to screw up a strawberry and nutella crepe.
author: Debbie C.

description:
I'll give them 3 really strong stars. The staff are truly friendly. And if I was working in this area, the influx of tourists, Charlie Chaplin vagabond-wannabes, and residents alike could indefinitely test my patience; however, show up with a smile on your face and those working will be surprisingly warm, friendly and helpful. This marks the second time I've been here, and while the first time was as Joanie S. said, a totally "random place", the food is not too, too shabby. 

Why only 3 stars? Apart from the awesome decor, which has a slightly Neoclassicist feel ( that is - the place is slightly ancient looking harking to antiquity with a sour garden palette - but I love that), the food might look decent on a plate but leaves much to be desired: I got the Eggs Florentine (soft poached eggs on spinach and English muffin with Hollandaise sauce) with salad and side of bacon. The sauce was runny and not the best flavor, still, edible and if you had a hangover, like Joanie S., definitely a safe spot to consume for your seemingly disintegrating frontal lobe. The egg whites were runny, which if you order soft poached, the eggs should always be cooked solid while leaving the yolks soft - not all of it soft and gelatinous and looking like a chicken sneezed rather than hatched its egg. The side salad was your typical iceberg mix with a dressing that looking somewhat distinguishable as balsamic vinaigrette (although I'm suspicious). The bacon was the one saving grace and had an excellent crisp finish (thank you: yum). I finished the meal off with a cup of earl grey tea while I was serenaded by the "Best of...80's Spanish Soap Opera Ballads" - save me please. 

At least the wifi is free, they have lemon-cucumber water, orange-peel water, and plenty of condiments for all those particulars people prefer for their meals. Overall, the place is a cute little tarnished gem that just needs a little "101 schooling" on playlists and poached eggs; other than that, it's safe and swell. Go eat!
author: Gio M.

description: North Beach crepe with hollandaise on the side was delicious. Don't like the omelette and great eggs benedict!  My sons loved the Nutella crepe. The line is long so come before you are hungry.
author: Katherine T.

description: I'm not sure what's the hype about this place. Maybe I ordered the wrong items, but I was completely unimpressed with the food. Overall really mediocre. My salmon Benedict just didn't taste like anything. The eggs didn't go with the smoked salmon, or the tomato, or the dry English muffin. The potatoes were lukewarm and were hard and dry.  I didn't even enjoy the latte. It wasn't hot enough and it tasted burned and bitter. It's just an ordinary breakfast place in the Union Square area. If you are looking for something special, don't come here. If you just need convenience and a place to fill up your stomach, then this place is fine. (Now I just wish I had gone and tried Dotties instead!!!)
author: Cecilia C.

description: My sister and I wanted to try this place out because we don't live in the city and we love crepes. We were visiting. We come in place wasn't packed but it looked nice. We get up to register and the guy working the register was rude right off the bat. Not friendly atmosphere at all. We ordered our crepes. I ordered something very simple. Peanut butter, Nutella, and bananas that was it. With whip cream on the side. He brings us our deserts and mine I noticed was wrong. It had rice crispies on it, strawberries, peanut butter, bananas, and Nutella. I went to tell him and he was very rude about it bacially calling me a liar. I was as nice as I could be about it. He then took my plate and went to the back to tell the chef and the chef looked pissed and they were talking about it, I was standing right there. My sister noticed he rolled his eyes at me. But they were just talking about it and all upset going on and on... And one guy there was nice to me and talked to them. So I waited awhile my sister is almost done with hers. I get mine and it's wrong again. He gave me just peanut butter, bananas, and no Nutella... I didn't bother telling him because I just felt uneasy talking to him. He was not friendly at all. Will NEVER GO BACK THERE AGAIN. I didn't even wanna rate this place 1 star. It deserves negative stars. I've never felt so disrespected in any restaurant. Berkeley has the best crepes. Way better service. Friendly atmosphere.
author: Christy P.

description:
On the morning my friend and I were set to leave The City, we decided to stop for breakfast (Thanks to Yelp!). 

Even on a holiday Monday, the place was packed with what I could assume were tourists and locals alike. The only downside is that you have to order at the counter and find a seat. I was able to snag a table while my boyfriend ordered but I could assume this would be a pain in the buns if you were trying to eat alone. 

The menu is BIG. I was kind of overwhelmed. My boyfriend ordered the chorizo and eggs and was VERY pleased. It definitely packed a punch of heat! I ordered the Eggs Benedict but was disappointed in the ham. It was so tough I couldn't even cut through it with the knife they provided. Pork faux pas. :(

As we were leaving, I noticed they had Nutella crepes and am really quite sad I didn't notice them on the menu. I will definitely have to order those the next time we are in town. All in all, it was a cute, inexpensive, tasty little joint for a hearty breakfast and a good cup of Joe. Hey, if the locals like it, it can't be that bad.
author: Maura H.

description: Cafeteria style restaurant. Wait in line while reading the menu, ordering food, and then try to find a place to sit down. Was pretty packed when we got there, but only took about five minutes before a table for four was available. Food was good and service was very friendly. Good vibe from locals here.
author: David G.

description: Fantastic, low key, friendly, fast, even when they are busy. More choices than I expected and everything I had was great. Had a late night Half moon bay crepe with a blintz for dessert. Went back in the morning for eggs benedict.
author: Eugene A.

description:
We randomly found this place, and what a hidden treasure.  We went for breakfast.  Their menu was quite extensive, but settled on a veggie omelette and my fiancé had the salmon Benedict.  WOW!!!   Big portions, tasty food, and very reasonable.  We wish we would have found it earlier so we could try it again.  We highly recommend this place.

Also, we went on a weekday, and after about 9am it was quiet and enjoyable.
author: Ally F.

description: I'm not sure how anybody could give this place less than 5 stars.  I ordered the Acapulco omelette, which excellent.  Even better is how they season the potatoes.  My wife ordered the croissant sandwich.  It was big and outstanding (I hate a bite).  We also shared the crepe suzette.   You have to try this.  INCREDIBLY GOOD!  Best breakfast I've had in a while.
author: J R.

description: Nice place for breakfast. I liked my eggs benedict. The Bloody Mary was barley drinkable. The counter service to get your order in was in need of some help. One girl taking orders and making drinks slowed things down and the line was to the door. Once past that though the food was good.
author: DJ V.

description: I was really hungry one morning running late to work but I really wanted to try this place. I've lived by Union Square for 2 years now and always passed by. So I gave it a try and was highly disappointed, it took forever to get my food and it was worse since I was in a rush, I had to ask for them to give me my food when it was already ready and just sitting there. I got my food and was so disappointed in the crab cake crepe that I had gotten, it was like burnt and tasted not that good at all, along with the potatoes fucking disgusting. Never eating here again, not worth it.
author: C Z.

description: My Pesto Crepe this morning was unique and delicious and my husband's Breakfast Crepe was simple and tasty. The potatoes were seasoned to perfection. Definitely try the fresh squeezed OJ and fresh carrot juice as both are sweet and amazing. The atmosphere was nice and the staff was friendly. I liked the wait in line to order and then seat yourself style of dining, it was fast considering the long line when we arrived.
author: Nicole H.

description: Wasn't expecting to find such a gem. Couple blocks from the hotel stumbled upon Honey Honey to find delicious, innovative dishes at a reasonable price. Across the table there were French toast, croissant breakfast sandwich, granola and fruit, crab cake florentine, chorizo scramble, and Italian sausage breakfast. Raving review from all dishes. Definitely making my way back here again.
author: Megan K.

description: This restaurant  is to be missed not only because the food is just mediocre (and therefore over-priced), but the man who was working when I was there last night (not sure if he is the owner or not) is rude and not very attentive to his customers.  I stood in line for a few minutes and waited for a woman to finish her order, then her husband came up to pay and a conversation ensued as the two men appeared to be from the same culture and spoke the same language; this kept me waiting for about 5 more minutes.  Then, interestingly enough, this same customer complained about something (I think it was one of his dishes) and the same employee began to berate him loudly enough so I and others could hear.  He kept saying, "Next time read the menu. Next time read the menu."  So, I for sure will  never return to this place and hope others will save themselves money and
author: Jack S.

description:
Went here on our last morning in S.F.  Walking distance from our Hotel.   This was our best breakfast in S.F.  Betterr than Lori's Diner, Sears Fine Food and Olympic Cafe.   My son had Chocolate Chip Waffles.  He couldn't eat it fast enough.  My hubby had the Breakfast Crepe and Lox & Bagels.   He really enjoyed them both.   I had the Chicken Pesto Crepe.  OMG!   It stuck with me till late afternoon.   I don't know about the coffee.  My son had it but didn't want a refill.  Maybe they need to try another brand of coffee.  
I do recommend this to the tourists if you're thinking of going to the above mentioned other breakfast spots.   Try Honey Honey instead.  You will probably thank me in the end.
author: Marla G.

description:
I came up to San Fran for a weekend getaway because I had never been before. We wanted to try something local and this was the PERFECT choice!! First of all the mimosas are FABULOUS. They are made with freshly squeezed orange juice. 

What really got 5 stars was the eggs benedict. Wow it was amazing! I made a great choice. I also got a nutella crepe and that was also tasty! I would totally go back if I am ever in town and I recommend this place as a breakfast spot to travelers.
author: Brittanee T.

description:
Thank you yelpers for helping me find this great place for brunch. It's a small place right on the corner of Post, I imagine if you come here during rush time its will be hard to get a seat.

My friend had the salmon benedict and it looked scrumptious, I had a crepe called acapulco or something ( i can't find it on the menu but its there). It was different with black beans and salsa, just the right amount of kick. And yes as the other yelper had mentioned the food is not too greasy. The potatoes could be yummier since I've had better but hey overall no complains. The water was orange flavored or lemon which was a nice touch. 

I also ordered the vanilla tea which was really tasty and I definitely can't wait to come back and try other delicious items on their menu. 

Thanks fellow yelpers for this great find.
author: Ashleen C.

description:
If you are from the East Bay/Berkeley, then the easiest way to describe this place is - almost exactly like Crepevine!

I came here at around noon on a Sunday for my good friend's birthday brunch. Another friend in our group waited in line for us, but I believe she had to wait at least 30 minutes!! Come early/way late if you want to avoid the wait. Even past 1pm, there were times when the line was going out the door.

I got the North Beach savory crepe and it was absolutely delicious. I loved the hollandaise sauce and how much chicken they gave. My one suggestion would be to have avocado! Then again, I'd probably like avocado in everything. It came with an option of fries, fruit, or salad, and I chose the last option because I can never turn down a good salad. Boy was I satisfied with my choice - they have a really nice vinegrette here! It was a very filling meal for ~$10.

The only reason I would not give this 5 stars is because I know I can get the same quality food for the same prices, but in much bigger portions at Crepevine (since I live in Berkeley). However, I would still highly recommend this brunch destination for anyone living in SF or wanting to shop near Union Square :)
author: Jenny M.

description: Seriously the best crepe my husband and I have ever had. I highly recommend the Nutella Banana crepe with ice cream. We had it for dessert two nights in a row. The counter service was a little slow the morning we went for breakfast but the food was amazing. I had pancakes and the chicken sausage (which wasn't my fav) and hubby had an omelet. Four days in San Francisco and we ate breakfast here once and dessert twice. I highly recommend.
author: Julie B.

description: It takes about 20 minutes to order food. Such a long time to waste for a mediocre food.
author: Mert Y.

description:
I think Honey Honey Cafe is one of the best creperies in San Francisco, they have a nice casual atmosphere with friendly staff and huge selection of food besides crepes such as pasta, sandwiches, omelettes and burgers. I have tried following items so far:

*Chicken Pesto Crepe - My favorite
*Miami Heat Crepe - It is spicy but OK
*Mexican Salad- I think it is the best salad here
*Warm Chicken Salad - Not better than Mexican Salad
*Grilled chicken sandwich - Good filling cheesy chicken sandwich
*Nutella Banana Crepe - Anything is good with Nutella :)

Just keep in mind that it gets packed and has long line on weekend mornings, but it is worth to wait.
author: U G  L C.

description: Although this restaurant appears to have an extensive and appetizing, menu the food is alas poor quality and for lack of a better word "whatever." My main issue is the man seemingly in charge was undeniably rude with a terrible attitude and was not very helpful or accommodating. This paired with food thats not that special gets you about 2 stars. Adding to this the decor and atmosphere was dingy and bleak at best. Would not recommend unless no other options are available to you or maybe you're just hungry and hungover and refusing to go very far.
author: N O.

description: The fact that this place has such a high rating is beyond me, and in my opinion misleading. The first impression: the establishment itself looks like a worn down fast food joint - vomit green walls, tacky and greasy plastic furniture. We entered and waited by the "wait here to be seated" sign. And waited... Untill a waiter happened to pass by to tell us to order at the counter (?). Fine. We ordered 2 crepes, 1 mimosa and 1 hot cider, which the waiter had a hard time to remember, even though the place was practically empty. We got the mimosa right away, which was not a mimosa but a white wine with a spash of OJ poorly presented. After finding a seat, we noticed a pipe had burst in the ceiling and was dripping. They had placed a towel at the floor to fix it (?). Food arrives - not a bad meal, but definitely not a good one, mediocre at best. The "hot cider" we ordered nerver showed up so we asked for it again. The waiter said "oh okay I will fix it" ... But it never showed up! Again, the place was practically empty! All in all - food, service, interior and overall experience was way belowe average. There are plenty of good places to eat in SF so I'd stay far away from this place.
author: Christine N.

description:
I give them 4 stars for service. We had a matinee play to make and I was concerned with the number of us, we would have a hard time finding a place to sit down. They immediately put me as ease, plus they offered my parents a place to sit while we ordered since they didn't have a place open for us just yet.

Yummy food; great service; great price... what's not to like?
author: Michelle S.

description: Prices are GREAT, Servers weren't all that friendly but they weren't rude. The food is pretty good--I feel I make better crepes at home, but the diversity of their food was pretty cool. Their cappuccinos are yummy licious. This is the only stop we made more than once. On the weekends be prepared for a wait---and you can't save a table.
author: Domo H.

description: If I could, I would give this place 4.5 stars. I ordered the tofu scramble and the balance of flavor was excellent; it comes with potatoes in the side and is topped with cilantro and green peppers. Also, the service here was surprisingly great. My dad was shaking some pepper onto his dish and the cap fell off, so the whole bottle of peppercorn ended up on his food. The line was extremely long and we thought it would take them forever to replace it, but thy were able to have it out in 3 minutes. That's the kind of service that small businesses should be striving for.
author: Tal M.

description: Very cozy. Very considerate and very welcoming staff. Only stopped by for a quick snack so I can't comment on the food too much but I will going back by at the next available chance.
author: David T.

description: This is my favorite cafe in the city - it's run by a beautiful family and the food is fantastic!  Make sure to try the warm chicken salad.
author: Tyler B.

description: Very nice looking place. The breakfast was ok....nothing spectacular. Don't be fooled by the long lines. We ordered three different plates. The bagels were tough to eat...almost like gum. The house coffee was bad. 711 has better coffee. The post omelet was boring. Potatoes were not crisp nor cooked thoroughly. The service was ok. Maybe it just me but not impressed by San Francisco food so far.
author: Daniel M.

description: No table service. Long line to order. If you're looking for good coffee don't count on getting it here. Had the breakfast crepe. Ok not great. Potatoes were tasty. It was ok bit nothing to go out of your way for that's for sure. Could have had just as good of a meal at mg hotel.
author: Stephanie H.

description: Complimentary orange infused water was delicious. I ordered the florentine crepe and it was very good. However, it was very small and didn't leave me filled. Very warm atmosphere and friendly staff.
author: Sydney P.

description:
Woke up yesterday not knowing what I wanted to eat - breakfast, lunch, brunch... luckily yelp's high reviews brought me here!

They serve everything from crepes, omelettes, pasta, salad, burgers... pretty much anything your heart desires!  I had the chicken pesto crepe and to my surprise - the pesto wasn't overpowering, just the perfect amount of pesto!  My boyfriend had the North Beach crepe, which had amazing flavor!  Each crepe had just the right amount of ingredients and no ingredient overpowered the other!  Even better, with the mimosas you get 90% champagne and 10% OJ compared to other places that give you 50/50!

Nice low key local joint with friendly staff and plenty of menu items to try!
author: Vanessa P.

description:
Loved this place! Was there on a Sunday AM while vacationing in SF mid-August. Not fancy, order at the counter, super reasonable. 

The only problem is deciding what to get. We shared a Nutella Banana Walnut crape & the salmon Benedict. They didn't stand a chance, we devoured them both.
author: Suzanne G.

description:
My "friend" swoooooore by this.

"You MUST get the crepes." 
"I come here at least once a week."
"I think you are awesome." (nothing to do with Honey Honey, but she did say it).

So yes, I came and got a breakfast crepe with "friend" on a Sunday morning. If we had shown up 5 minutes later... I would've been stuck behind 10+ more crepe-seeking SFers. So yes, this place can get busy.

I enjoyed the crepe. But I must say, the potatoes that accompanied the crepe was quite an accessory for a carb-craving eater like myself.

Would come back here... but not at night... because (1) it's probably not open, and (2) sketcherloin is not somewhere one should visit once the sun goes down.
author: Victor C.

description:
Went there with a friend this morning after seeing all the positive reviews - that and it was close to my hotel. The inside is nice enough and the menu is massive (literally big). It takes up the entire side of a wall. I have poor eyesight and could read the thing from way across the room.

Both my friend and I got the crab florentine. I had a coffee and she had the orange juice. The coffee was nothing special. Her orange juice however, came out of a nifty looking machine that had a bin of orange at the top and would funnel them into line to have them split in half and then crush each half to extract the juice. Fun to watch and you have no doubt that it's "fresh". 

The crab cake florentine is pretty much what you would expect. Tasty but light on the crab. Mostly egg and english muffin. I suspect the crab cake was in there somewhere. The potatoes on the side were pretty awful though. They were so dry that even after two swigs of coffee I was having trouble getting all the pieces down. I had one bite and called it quits. I'm rubbing my tongue inside my mouth as I type this thinking about how dry it was. Ughhh.

So their benedicts/florentine aren't terrible but their potatoes sure are. Haven't tried their crepes but would be willing to give them a shot.
author: Brian T.

description: Crepes are great! I like the food here and ate here twice while visiting SF. I came for dinner so have not experienced the breakfast awesomeness described by others. However for a light dinner that fills you up, doesn't cost too much (rare in that area) this is the place. First visit I felt the service was a a little surly but typical for a high tourist area. But second visit I must have encountered the owner because he was delightful and the service was great! My only suggestion was it could be a little bit cleaner. But don't let that hold you back!! I will return...
author: L S.

description: Homey delicious food was on the bill here. Great suggestion from our concierge at our hotel. Food was great, atmosphere a delight and busy busy busy.
author: Victoria S.

description:
Whats the hype about?

Waited in line 30 min which is fine. 

All staff were very friendly, professional and funny. Quite remarkable considering how busy they were.

Price I guess is average. 2 adults and 2 kids usd 50.

Food was nothing to write about and was same as you would find in any better diner. Typical standard American cafe.  Croissants and oj were fantastic, though.
Hollandaise sauce not home made or if homemade then blended.

Would be a good place in a smaller town but in SF there are much better alternatives
author: Andreas S.

description:
My boyfriend and I stopped in here for breakfast this morning and at first weren't sure if we wanted to wait in the long line - but it was worth it.  The line moved faster than we thought and soon enough it was our turn to order.

I ordered the pancakes with a side of bacon and my boyfriend chose the SPK crepe.  Our order came pretty fast and it was tasty.  I loved my pancakes and they were just right - soft and with powdered sugar on top!  The bacon wasn't too crispy or soft and was delicious.  
My boyfriend's crepe came with whipped cream on the side and he devoured the whole thing.  Next time he and I are in SF we'll probably come back here, maybe just a little earlier to avoid the long line at the register.
author: Rachel M.

description: While the food was tasty, the line to order moved extremely slowly while we were there. And that is because the lady who was taking orders had to deliver the food as well. when a 2nd server came in while we were still in line, it moved much quicker. I had the post street omelette and my husband had the pesto crepes. we enjoyed both.
author: Alfonsina S.

description: Simple, yet good! When you walk in, there's a big menu board to your right. You order food, they give you a table number and they'll bring the food to your table. I got two scrambled eggs with toast and potatoes with orange juice. Orange juice was freshly squeezed in front of me so you know there's no sugar added. Good and fresh food - I felt healthy walking out of that joint.
author: Jesse N.

description:
I had a friend bring me here one hungover Sunday morning in the rain. I honestly thought I was going to pass out and die, and did NOT want to be here, but I tried my best to suck it up and get some food in my belly.

I ordered the Acapulco Omelette, and it changed my life while simultaneously curing my hangover. I love Mexican food more than I love my mother, so this was an epiphany. This small egg wallet, filled with black beans, cheese and avocados blew my mind, and I'm guessing the eggs and avos are what cured my hangover so fast.

Go here, eat, be merry.
author: Tyler H.

description:
Let's just say as a vegan, I'm not apt to patronize an establishment where its name is a substance I don't normally consume. I decided to checkout anyway since it came up when I Yelp'd 'vegan brunch.'

As far as I was considered, my options (vegan) were rather limited. While they do have a tofu scramble dish on their menu, it comes with eggs, smoked tofu, green pepper, onion, cilantro. While I'm not entirely opposed to the idea, typically a tofu scramble contains what the name implies, TOFU, not also egg. The counter girl seemed confused with I ordered the Tofu Scramble with just tofu and not egg. She thought I only wanted tofu in my scramble.

After that awkward experience, the food itself wasn't much better. You think if you order an dish without one of the ingredients then they would augment the dish with the remaining ingredients to make up for said missing item. No, this was not the case. Overall, the dish was palatable but nothing remarkable. Thankfully, I had also ordered a fruit cup which aided in satiating my hunger. Not sure how you can do it but the fruit cup was equally awkward containing predominately apple slices.

While I'm not opposed to the idea of restaurants opening where others weren't as successful, I find it annoying when the new owners don't go the distance to differentiate the space and interior from the previous tenant. Other then maybe the menu boards and a bad coat of paint, the interior looks like it hasn't changed. Despite occupying a prime corner spot in the building, the space was dreary and drape, definitely not feeding my visual appetite.

If I lived in San Francisco, I don't think I would count myself as one of their regulars but I might pay them a visit out of a matter of convenience.
author: Hael F.

description: Gross. This place has a "I don't care any more" attitude. It's dirty. The sign is dirty, the place is very dark. I ordered the granola and fruit with yogurt. Bleh. The yogurt was not cold, the granola was stale. It was an overall bad experience. I hope I don't get food poisoning. Not going there again, I don't recommend it.
author: Andie A.

description:
Honey Honey rocks my socks. 
I'm rather bummed that they don't have another location around 502 miles south of San Fran. 

Why I think this place is kickin': I hate eggs. I cannot stand eggs unless they're in pastry (cake, cookie, etc) form. And I ate an omelet at Honey Honey. The Acapulco omelet, to be exact. Sho good. 
The Nutella crepes are uber yummy. I love how they make orange juice right in front of you. I want one of those machines..

I'd be more than willing to five star Honey Honey.. But every time I've gone (which is five or six times over the span of two years), the rosemary 'tatoes have been sandpaper dry. Like, not even heaps of ketchup help.
author: Alfa S.

description: I live close by and come here fairly often for coffee. I'm a bit of a healthy food freak and somewhat of a picky eater, so there are few things that I will actually eat off the menu here (carrot juice, toast, vegetable chillie, or garden salad) but all are delicious and satisfying.
author: None Of Your Business B.

description: Good food but very rude employees/owners.  We got there 15 minutes before they were going to close and were told we only could get to go food. A group of 5 just before us was just getting their drinks and waiting for the food they just ordered. It didn't make sense.
author: Ann B.

description: Honey honey is alright. It's not very welcoming. I never feel very comfortable there. Aside from that the food pretty good, but not cheap. If you're looking for a solid $10 breakfast with no atmosphere this place will get the job done.
author: Nick N.

description:
It being early on a weekday, there wasn't a long line - there wasn't any line in fact, as they had just opened. So for those of you who don't want to wait, go early!

Had the pesto crepe - YUM! It was filled with big chunks of readily identifiable ingredients - huge chunks of avocado and feta and lots of pesto, tomato and pine nuts. The fruit was the same - really nice and ripe and big, hand-cut chunks, not the unripe small squares that you get at some breakfast places. 

Annoying music, so took the food to go, but they have a huge eating area with a nice mix of small and larger tables to accomodate their clearly long lines later in the day.
author: Lisa B.

description:
This has become my goto breakfast spot within walking distance from home (and conveniently located between Nob Hill and the FiDi so it's on my way to work as well). It can get crowded on the weekend, so plan accordingly.

Great food. Everyone else seems to harp on the crepes (which I'm sure are good but have never tried), so I'm going to focus on the other items. I dig the chorizo scramble a lot. The lox scramble (or omelette?) was also worth getting. Top it all off with a glass of fresh squeezed orange juice, and baby you've got a breakfast!

A few interesting things about Honey Honey:
 - Complimentary orange or cucumber flavored water
 - The benches built into the wall are a few inches too high and you notice it when you start eating
 - Free wifi!
author: Adam D.

description: Pleasant enough place, lots of sandwiches, salads, crepes, you can hang out here, use the computer. Fairly nondescript but a wide selection, good prices, healthy well prepared food and comfortable large interior. We have lots of places like this in town, this is one of them.
author: Gil S.

description:
Uber long wait (on a Thursday morning even...that's how you know it's bomb) and I was extremely hungover...BUT I AIN'T MAD AT 'EM!
The wait was well worth the ridiculously delicious breakfast we ravaged...and of course, the Bloody Mary. 
(Yes, they serve bloodies!!)

The eggs benedict and french toast rocked my world--So I will most definitely be back. Great breakfast places are really few and far between.
author: Bree P.

description:
Being from Reno - a town notoriously bereft of ANY crepery, let alone a good one - I relish any opportunity to make it to the Bay Area to indulge.  Honey Honey is, without a doubt, the best and most consistent sit-down crepery in SF.  

The staff are excellent, no matter if the place has a line out the door or if you're the only one there.  They have stopped looking at me strangely when I order one of their fresh-squeezed Mimosas in a pint glass (they're just too good to be relegated to a 3oz wine glass) and the crepes are always fluffy, flavorful, and jammed to the brim with excellent ingredients.  

My wife orders the Crab Cake Florentine while I usually stick to the standard ham, egg, cheese breakfast crepe.  The use of Herbs du Provence on the potatoes creates a wonderfully crisp exterior and soft interior to the side dish.  Rarely do they require any seasoning, which is amazing.

Finally, I have to confess that there have been weekend mornings where the undying need for their crepes overrides everything else and I jump in the car for a quick 3-hour jaunt to SF.  Yes, that's a long way to go for a meal, but trust me it's well worth it.
author: Benjamin L.

description: Cute little breakfast place....place your order at the counter and then find a seat. Quick, friendly service and delicious crepes! I had the pesto crepe and my 2 companions also loved it. The side potatoes were also good. I tried my husband's crab cakes egg benedict and it was good but I have had much better. I would definitely go back and I would stick to the crepes.
author: Malena A.

description:
I think they do two things well: breakfast/lunch, and pre-theatre dinner. They have a huge selection of omelets -- of which I'm a fan -- as well as some of the usual pancake/French toast stuff. But their main thing is really crepes, for which they also have a huge selection of both savory and sweet. They also have a few pasta dishes and a decent hamburger, with full espresso/Italian soda service as well as the usual beverage selection.
Perfectly fine place to go, and a great budget-conscious selection. I would say that if they were anywhere in SF, but being in that part of town, it's a phenomenal deal, and I can't believe they're not more full in the evenings. Guess it's not fancy enough if you want a 'night out' kind of place, but for comfort food before an evening's entertainment, can't be beaten.
author: Christopher P.

description: Good food but not worth the price. Very expensive
author: Craig T.

description:
Service was friendly, food brought out quick. Free coffee refill. Good coffee. Cold water that you serve yourself (two types: flavored with oranges AND flavored with lemons and mint). Not a fancy, snobby place, but its a nice decor / well lit place. Casual place. Good vibes from the workers. Big menu plus some daily specials. 

When my bacon cheeseburger didn't have bacon on it, I panicked. 
Cheeseburger = good
Bacon cheeseburger = magic!!!
I told the woman about the missing bacon I had a plate of bacon brought to me in about sixty seconds. Not sure if they accidently put avocado on my burger since I didn't notice it on the menu, but I liked it. Bread was fresh and above average. I also got more fries than I needed. 

Plenty of tables and wireless internet (not sure how many electric outlets were accessible) so you can do your projects. Nobody else was using their computer, so I was shy to pull mine out. 
A great success.
author: Alex S.

description:
I really, really love this place.  Probably too much.  

My first week at my new job I discovered the Double H, and I haven't looked back.  They make me like salad.  Salad not disguised by gobs of ranch dressing.  I am not a fan of roughage unless I can make it somehow unhealthy.  Honey Honey has given me a salad a whole new beginning.  Their house vinaigrette is some seriously tasty stuff. 

They've rocked my lunch hour with their crispy, delicious potatoes nestled in next to my apple turkey sandwich.  They've saved my day with a steaming bowl of some of the best chicken noodle soup this side of anywhere.  They've been kind enough not to judge me when I come in three times a week (I told you I might have a problem).  

Lately, I've cut down to once a week because I don't want to ruin it for myself.  Yes, my friends, that is a sacrifice you make only when you can't stand the thought of wearing a place out!

They are awesome for take out, which means a lot when I'm running back to the office on a busy day and forget to double check for silverware or napkins.  I've never been scared of their containers leaking either!  Eating inside the restaurant has its benefits too, and the whole place has a cheery feel that is sure to brighten even the dreariest San Francisco Day.
 
Bottom line: Seriously though, I'll probably be back up to multiple times a week soon.  I'm okay with it.
author: Kellie T.

description:
I came here in search of a good brunch place in SF. My boyfriend doesn't believe in brunch. I came here to try to prove him wrong. Boy was that a mistake. 

Their crepes are subpar. Everything tastes like it's been put through a mediocre machine. There is no reason to come HERE when there a bunch of other legit brunch places in SF. 

And to top it all off, I felt like a lump on a log afterward. That sealed the deal. Not coming back!
author: Angeline P.

description: It's kinda busy but very quick also! We tired the crepes they had and they were really good! We also tried the chicken sandwich and it was good and the Athens omelet! Everything was good and it's a very cute cozy place to have brunch or breakfast at!
author: Fatimah A.

description: The bald man taking our order was super rude. Didn't even speak to us. Just took our order and gave us our drinks and let us be on our way. I had the crab cake florentine. "Poached eggs" were hard boiled and the whole dish tasted disgusting. My husband had juevos rancheros. He also didn't like his dish. Tasted old and bland. Unfortunate because I've had the chef salad here, to-go and it was good. Also the music was super annoying and didn't go with the theme of the place. Pretty sure it was Mylie Cyrus but idk because when they didn't like a song it would change to the next crappy song. Ugh. Not going back.
author: Kristen V.

description: My favorite place to pick up breakfast when I'm in the city. I would suggest the salmon benedict, it's my favorite. I've also eaten the french toast here which is really and I love the orange juice here! The orange juice is squeezed from real oranges which is delicious! The place does get pretty loud especially during their rush hour times. Take it to go if you can!
author: Elaine M.

description: So great. Lots of vegetarian options, and service is superfast. Get the Acapulco omelette.
author: Sean M.

description: Very very slow kitchen and cashier- long lines at 10:00am.  Took over an hour just to put in order.   Food is decent but I would rather not waste over 2 hours in the city for a breakfast.   You can connect to the wifi but don't expect to get any service.  Yup, wifi is very very slow too.
author: TS L.

description: It's a  crepery, so definitely order the crepes! Ordered oatmeal and bacon as well, both were average. The strawberry and Nutella crepe was definitely the shining star of he show. The crepe perfectly balanced the Nutella with the strawberry and the whipped cream put it over the top.  Super casual vibe and seating wasn't hard to come by even though there was a crowd. One thing I would add is that this isn't the kind of place that you're encouraged to linger (this is how the crowd is able to move), so if you're meeting up with someone you haven't seen in awhile and want to catch up, you may want to choose something else.
author: Erin M.

description:
This is the best breakfast spot in the Bay Area!  If you love breakfast...

Honey Honey is the best!

Hands Down....
author: Chris R.

description: Absolutely delicious and reasonable priced!!! I ate here 4 days in a row when I was in town and very impressed with the quality of food.
author: Laura C.

description:
Was here twice while in San Francisco for a couple of weeks. The menu is excellent and the prices offer good value. They have free WiFi and a glass of wine is half the price here than most places! A glass of wine was typically 8/9 dollars everywhere and here it was only 4.
I would definitely recommend this place, had the crab cake sandwich and it was excellent. My girlfriend was also very pleased with her choices on both occasions.

I like crab cake sandwiches........if you like crab cake sandwiches go here!
author: Gavin D.

description: Possibly due to a long wait and slow order taking, the end result was not worth the wait. Had an omelet which came with potatoes. Potatoes were very mushy, probably because they are just sitting in the back over cooking. Omelet was nothing exciting. Had to order a side of protein so there was enough food to count as breakfast. Bread side was dry with no options to help it out. Wife had a two, two and two. Bacon was hard and oily. Pancakes were chewy, not the best I had this weekend. Overall, not matching the Yelp ratings with better options in the area at the same price.
author: Warren S.

description:
Dear Counter Dude, 
Sorry I inconvenienced you by ordering...food.  And not complicated 'non-fat double shot soy vegan espresso' food or anything.  I said, "I would like the salmon sandwich, please."  Apparently, this was a massive headache for you.

The sandwich was pretty crap-a-licious.

You get two stars because you have quality iced tea and good french fries.
author: Logan K.

description:
I stopped in here for a lunch bite one day and breakfast the next. On lunch bite day, I had an order of lentil soup with a caesar salad. It was later in the day and there was no lineup, but there were also a bunch of dishes still left on the tables. By a bunch I mean 5. It felt a little unkept and made finding a clean table to sit at while waiting for my food a little challenging. I think maybe I just hit them at a bad time, however, because 15 minutes later, the tables were all cleared and wiped down. The soup was alright, though a pretty small bowl. The caesar salad was large, but nothing worth writing any more about.

So where does the four star rating come from? Breakfast the next day. Oh yes! Honey Honey can do breakfast quite well. Right down the the freshly squeezed orange juice. So fresh, the juice had been full, intact, unpeeled oranges only minutes before. The Acapulco Omelette was also very satisfactory, and the hashbrowns it came with, well, I know some more mediocre breakfast places that could take a lesson or two from those hashbrowns.

Service was quick and efficient, the server bringing me my food even asked if I wanted some butter and jam. When I said yes, he brought over a bowl full of butter packages and an entire tray of jam, not the processed kind in packages, but three kinds sitting in little pots with spoons to dish them out. There was also no butter on my toast to begin with, so I got to decide how much or how little went on there. During the busiest of brunch hours, Honey Honey prevailed. Fours stars, all the way.
author: Wendy P.

description: Great breakfast. Pecan pancakes rock. Nice atmosphere. Free wifi. Fresh OJ. Good coffee.
author: Mark F.

description:
After staying in town last week and encountering some of the slowest fuggin' WiFi I've ever experienced in my life at Hotel Monaco, Honey Honey became my unofficial home office. There were plenty of different spots that had free wireless internet in the area, but I really connected with this particular place.

Sometimes, coffee shops are too much of a scene for me to handle. I don't want to compete for attention with a gaggle of weird emo kids who didn't get enough attention from their fathers growing up... I just want some caffeine. While I ran into plenty of those last week, Honey Honey was anything but a hangout for java snobs. Absolutely no pretentiousness from the staff or patrons, and it had a great vibe from folks reading the newspaper, reading various books... and of course, enjoying the free WiFi action.

They have a pretty wide array of food stuffs available as well. Everything from soup, sandwiches, pancakes, scrambles, bagel sandwiches and more. I went with the mozzarella, basil and tomato bagel the only time I actually ate there, and it was solid. Almost tasted like a miniature pizza. 

The coffee is nothing to write home about, but it did the trick.

Overall, a great place to grab a relatively quick breakfast without feeling like you should have your nose pierced or have a sleeve full of tattoos to feel comfortable.
author: Ruggy J.

description: I work at a hotel down the street and ALWAYS recommend people here. But why?! Stopped by my lunch break for a Pasta. Made me sick. Was sweet enough to give it another try. Flavorless. And the garlic bread? Look at the picture. Really? I wasted $12 on this meal. Shoulda went to Walgreens and gotten a snack like i originally planned....
author: A R.

description:
Great menu selection and free wi-fi. 

I usually drop in when I can work out of the office and need a change in scenery. The food is great breakfast fare, eggs, bacon, crepes, and more eggs. I've had almost every item on the menu. 

Staff is very friendly and accommodating. A real treasure of a restaurant/cafe and a few blocks from Union Square.
author: B C.

description: I had the Santa Fe special.  I'm from Texas and the Santa Fe is like migas without all the cheese.  The corn tortilla strips were crispy and the eggs were seasoned well.  Jalapeños gave it a pleasant spiciness.  Loved it here!
author: Edward R.

description: Great menu, chill atmosphere and it can get breakfast ANYTIME of day. Plus free wifi. Loved it!
author: Trisha J.

description:
When I want a crepe, for both my savory or sweet cravings, I come to this places for 3 reasons: 

1. Their crepes are consistent. I haven't had a bad one so far. 
2. There's usually no line which means no waiting. But I guess it's not so good for business, but it's definitely good when I don't have much time. 
3. Good atmosphere. You can sit there and have long conversations with friends without feeling pressured to leave. 

I usually share a savory crepe AND a sweet crepe for one meal. It's portioned perfectly so I can enjoy halfsies of both!
author: Stephanie K.

description: I give 5 stars because of the customer service especially on a busy weekend like NikeSF Women's Marathon.  The food speaks for itself and the family that runs it does a pretty nice job of managing the restaurant.  You get a sense of locals and tourists to this establishment and they seem to get along quite well.  This family business does a great job of catering to all.
author: Anthony E.

description: Fine. Nothin spectacular. The eggs in the eggs Benedict were over cooked and barely runny. A properly poached egg is something special.  The hollandaise was very average. Wouldn't recommend it per say to someone visiting the city - there's gotta be better places.  In all fairness the crepes DO look awesome.
author: Marissa C.

description: I've lived up in northern California for 6 months now and this is my favorite breakfast so far. Great selections and great service!
author: Aaron H.

description: During our one week stay, we went to Honey Honey Cafe three times! Loved the breakfast as well as their crepes.
author: Mika N.

description: Came to SF for the weekend to run the Nike womens Marathon and stopped by this place for breakfast Saturday morning. The food was amazing. The restaurant was really clean and cozy and the prices were perfect for my budget. Two thumbs ups! Definitely will come back next time I'm in town.
author: Korina R.

description: Eggs Benedict w/ fruit was delicious! My friend ordered the original crepe and added avocado and it was pretty good too! The service was great and Katya was always one step ahead of you if you needed something. We studied for a few hours here and the ambience was good to get work done.
author: Natasha C.

description: The people are very friendly but I ordered a burger and fries that tasted like they had come out of a freezer and been put in the oven to give to me.
author: Katherine Y.

description:
I came here two days after having my first crepe at Crepe-A-Go-Go. I was really excited to try another crepe. The crepes at Honey Honey Cafe are a little too fancy if you ask me. When I had my banana and Nutella crepe at Crepe-A-Go-Go it was incredibly delicious because of how simple it was. But when I got the exact same crepe at Honey Honey, there was chocolate swirls on top of the crepe, and powdered sugar, and ice cream on the side, which sounds really great but it actually made it less enjoyable to eat because they was just so much going on. I guess I just prefer a more low key crepes.

The atmosphere here is really nice though. This is a great place to come on a Saturday or Sunday morning/early afternoon to read a book, study, or get some work done.
author: Andrew M.

description:
I can't speak for the crepes, but I did have an egg, ham and cheese croissant sandwich with potatoes on the side and fresh squeezed orange juice that was delicious.

 The free water with lemon and mint leaves was also a nice touch.
author: Edith G.

description: One of the best places I've eaten at. Savory crepes, sweet crepes, egg scrambles, hash brown potatoes...all delicious. Would be a regular if I lived in San Fran.
author: Ross H.

description: Good food but less than desirable brunch atmosphere. Dislike the ordering at the counter system personally. Coffee is overpriced w no refill. Pancakes were yum though!
author: Britt Q.

description: Super slow staff, arrived at 8:10 and took 15 min just to order...with only 3 in front of us.  Good food, would come again, just need more staff!
author: Heather M.

description: Delicious crepes! Breakfast potatoes are seasoned to perfection. Great drink selection... Italian cream sodas, mimosas, etc.
author: Katie C.

description:
The staff there is amazing. They remember me and even have my double cappuccino ready for me before I pay.  How nice is that?

I had a homeless guy come in and harass me.  The staff came out, ushered him out and everything. I felt a lil' safer because they actually were looking out!

I love their black bean chili-a regular on the menu.  Good for us low-carb dieters.
author: Stacey D.

description:
I eat here for breakfast and was reasonably happy with experience.  One observation: it's not a diner in the sense that you pay for your food at the counter and then they bring the food to your table.
I had the 2-2-2 and I have say the pancakes were delicious but the bacon was not crispy to my tastes.
author: ira b.

description:
Man, I really wanted to give this place more than 3 stars. It's cute inside, it's close to my house, the staff is really nice, the selection is vast, their free water with cucumbers and lemons is super refreshing, free wi-fi and a chalkboard menu (I love those!). But when reviewing a food place, one must remember that it comes down to the food. Is it good or not? Unfortunately, so far, I have only found the food okay. I have had a few things from here and they all lacked of flavor. A few days ago I had the crab cake florentine and kept waiting for the flavor to hit me but it never did. My friend ordered the same thing and he felt that it lacked in flavor as well. I had their cobb salad before and it was okay but I was disappointed that there weren't bleu cheese crumbles. 

Although the place has crepes in the name I have never had a crepe from here. I plan on going back and trying a crepe. I am hoping that their crepes will give me a reason to come back on here and add a star.
author: Liz M.

description:
Found this place on yelp after finishing up a half marathon in the city this weekend while desperately searching for a reasonably priced brunch with mimosas! Couldn't have been happier with our choice; out of this world pancakes and our server even brought a mimosa directly to our table when the line was too long to wait in to order another one. 

We will definitely be back!
author: Molly Q.

description: Vacationing in San Francisco and stumbled upon this gem of a breakfast place! We ate there every morning and I tried something new each time.  The breakfast is delicious, it's affordable and the service is fantastic!  I highly recommend the fresh squeezed OJ and carrot juice.  If you want to leave satisfied this is the place to go.  It did get a bit busy so there can be quite a wait, but it's worth it:)
author: Nica A.

description: Make a point to check the special menu whiteboard. Baklava crepes ought to be EPIC! I can't wait.
author: Dutch D.

description: We ordered salmon eggs benedict, chicken pesto crepe, and eggplant crepe. They were all good and the portion was generous. The service could be better, but overall a good experience.
author: Youbin J.

description:
This place is legit.

Nothing fancy, just good food. The husband and I went here for breakfast for our last day in the city. We were kind of in a rush and all the lines at the neighboring restaurants were way too long. 

We went in. looked at the huge menu that covers the entire wall, and it was a really hard decision to make. They have everything from crepes, pancakes, breakfast burritos. Whatever you heart desires. I ordered the tomato, basil, and mozzarella omelette. The hubby got the pecan pancakes. Our food took a while to get out because a family of 8 walked in right before us. Once it came out everything looked really good. Sadly my omelette was basically all tomatoes. I could barely taste the egg. I had to dig to find any basil and there was just a small amount of cheese. The hubbies pancakes were good, although the syrup was a little too sweet for me, and they gave him about 4 actual pecans. 

Would I come here again? Maybe if the other restaurants are too busy again. I like the variety of the menu so I'm sure I'm bound to find something yummy!
author: Ashley M.

description: Best french toast I've ever had! Not your typical boring french toast, there's so much flavor in theirs. The New Orleans crepe was equally delicious. The side of fruit was perfectly ripe. The fresh squeezed orange juice was perfect as well. Anytime I'm in SF this will be my go to breakfast spot.
author: Justine M.

description: Only went early in the morning during weekdays, but didn't have any of the issues with service or waits that others have mentioned. This became my go to spot for breakfast on a brief business trip to SF, and aside from my general shock at how expensive this city is (though can't blame Honey Honey for that), I could not have been happier to dine here. Friendly staff, wide selection, fresh ingredients, a pleasant atmosphere and all around good food breakfast food, whether savory or sweet. Plus fresh squeezed orange juice and coffee that's strong but not burned. What more can you ask for?
author: Jim S.

description: Great breakfast spot. Unfortunately I did not go with the crepes. My breakfast choice was the French toast, I don't know why, don't judge me. The choice I made turned out to be grade A. The toast was fluffy and we'll balanced, not too egg-y. The tea selection was pleasant, went with the blackberry. For a nice little air down cafe the prices are just right. If I'm in the area I'll grab a crepe next time, I promise!
author: Aaron B.

description:
I love Sunday brunching in SF, but I hate waiting over an hour to eat in tiny overrated restaurants. So luckily for me, I found this gem of a cafe. I'm giving them 1 whole star simply because we didn't have to wait to eat here! :)

Food: The menu on the wall is incredibly extensive, from omelettes to waffles to crepes, there is something affordable for everyone. I had the breakfast crepe which is really more tortilla than crepe. Tasted like a breakfast burrito with ham, onions, bell peppers, cheddar, and eggs. Served with a side of fruit. Nothing to write home about, but not bad. If you want authentic delicious crepes, go to Ti Couz. If your group can't decide what they want to eat, this is the place for you.  

Atmosphere: Friendly, casual, great place for groups. Did I mention there is no wait? ;)

Service: Order at the counter from the menu on the wall, get a number, grab a table and wait for your food to be served.
author: Connie C.

description: I had the blintz crepe with cheese, strawberry and marmalade - it was delicious. The wait time was a little longer than I would have liked and the OJ is overpriced but overall it was pretty enjoyable.
author: Joyce H.

description: Absolutely overrated, we got the sunrise burrito and chorizo scramble omelette, both has a distinctly mediocre taste, which after a 45 minute wait, it disappointed. Potatoes and fresh OJ salvaged what was otherwise a waste of $30.
author: Chris G.

description: It was very busy when we stopped in. Line out the door. It was hot as hell inside as well. Besides the long wait the food and drinks were very good. You seat yourself here and the tables were not very clean since there was no real bus boys. The layout is also kind of shitty. People in line are standing on top of the people eating. I'll pass next time.
author: Ikka S.

description: Great food, great staff, and the owner is a nice gentleman.    I promise you won't regret it.
author: Josh P.

description: Excellent Eggs Benedict. Properly cooked eggs, superb (light) hollandaise sauce, and nicely seasoned taters. Fair price for being in downtown SF.
author: Nicolas S.

description: Food was only okay. I am an eggs  Benedict aficionado and theirs was very lack luster and had a sweet taste every few bites which was off. Great great fresh squeezed orange juice though. Others at the table had French toast and huevos rancheros. French toast was adequate and the huevos were best of the bunch. Staff was very nice But I don't understand the reason they have counter service for ordering with food run out to table. Makes things loud and impersonal.  Price was okay. All in all, look elsewhere but you will be fine if this is only option.
author: Gigi S.

description: A nice breakfast spot with lots of options! There was a medium-sized line when we cam in, but you will need the extra time to decide what you want. The many crepes and egg options are a bit overwhelming, but I would wager they are almost all worth trying.
author: Daniel S.

description: I have a soft spot for Honey Honey - I often stop in for breakfast on my way to work - love their menu offerings from standard breakfasts to crepes, sandwiches, and salads. Very efficient service even when they're jam packed. There's not always someone coming by to offer coffee refills, but free refills are honored if I go up to ask for one at the cash wrap. My favorite items to order are the crab florentine, chorizo scramble, and the Miami Heat crepe.
author: Elaine W.

description:
I have been here 3 times and will never go again. Even at random times of the day, this place will have a line, but not bc it's busy, just bc they understaff it. There is seating for about 40 but since you order then go sit down you run in to the dilemma where people are all getting seats before ordering and then people who have done the right thing and waited in line before getting a seat get screwed.

Overall the food is  2-3 stars, it may be good enough for people who haven't been to many crepe places, but it has the typical formula with the chalkboard menu on the wall, cookie cutter food with nothing special on the menu. Had a lemon crepe which was the worst crepe I've ever had, for the eggs benedict they use a mold and don't actually poach there eggs and put way too much premade sauce on it...sandwiches are decent...
author: Joey P.

description: Fun place to start your day with some nice food...good portions and not bad price.  Place is usually packed but you wont wait much to be seated.  I ate here and the meal was good enough to hold my hunger until late afternoon...which was good for my travel experience because it gave me more time to enjoy the city
author: Luis M.

description:
Close to Hotel Nikko
Their Philly crepe was very greasy and not put together well, my fault for going safe in ordering. Had the chicken burrito as well, so the conservative ordering didn't allow for the restaurant to showcase its skills, until the dessert. The chocolate pecan crepe is very good complete with ice cream.
author: Gabe C.

description:
Tasty fresh orange juice. Ok eggs florentine - the hollandaise sauce was nothing special. The granola/yogurt/fruit was good. Hot inside and a bit of a line. We sat outside to eat.

All was very good and they have A LOT of options on the menu. The service was ok and you do not need the eggs florentine - Id recommend stickin with crepes
author: Jessica G.

description: Solid food choices. Menu was eclectic and varied. The child chose French toast and was pretty impressed with the amount on her plate. Fresh strawberries were a great topping on her meal. I chose the eggplant crepe and was really happy with it. Sundried tomatoes gave it a great flavor and it was just the right size. We rolled out with full tummies and only down $20. Worth checking out!
author: Christina W.

description: Loved it. Great breakfast-found something for us and the kids, healthy portions and all very tasty. Be there early, line snaked out the door by the time we were eating.
author: Piotr U.

description: This place was close to our hotel and looked great for breakfast - not a bad spot if you don't mind listening to techno on a Saturday morning. The menu selection was huge ... lots of egg dishes, crepes (seemed a little expensive - we paid almost $7 for a crepe with some lemon curd/jelly on top), and espresso/coffee.
