Although you order and pay from the front register, the food is delivered quickly and efficiently on tables cleaned just as well. But beyond the service, it's the people I love. The proprietor and his family are wonderful people who care about their customers, the neighborhood and it's residents. They'll remember you and what you like, offer treats to regular patrons, and, if your experience is anything like mine, ultimately befriend you.

Lastly, they offer free-wifi, are very friendly to children, and are open almost all the time. If you have a friend to meet staying downtown, this is the place. Great coffee, great snacks, great atmosphere, good location, caring staff, 5 stars.
author: Mitch H.

description:
You can't really go wrong with the name like Honey Honey in the 'Loin.  It was just about the only thing that looks open, clean and sober in the locale on a gloomy Saturday morning.  The place was abuzz with chatters from (primarily) tourists from nearby little hotels eager to get a head start and to kick off their day with a hearty (or healthy) breakfast. 

And really, the only reason I was there is because my out of town friends were staying in Hotel Diva around the corner, whose only breakfast option is day-old pastry from Starbucks next door.  

So we quickly perused the expansive menu on the board and settled for a variety of crepes.  I wasn't feeling it that morning after a messy Friday at Slide (also within a stone's throw) so I had a granola with yogurt and fruit slices and a glass of sweet, fresh-squeezed OJ.  

Delish.
author: Ange L.

description:
A few of us stumbled in, hungover, looking for some decent breakfast and crepes.  We live a few blocks away, and were unwilling to drag our sorry selves far or wait for a table.  From the look of it, we thought that it would be your usual Crepevine/Squat and Gobble affair. Wowwwww we were wrong. (We should have known better.  Union Square is a cesspool of substandard tourist traps.)
So the look of the menu, the seat yourself with a number, its all the standard.  Until the food came.  The "crepes" were strangely thick and overcooked, almost like chewy tortillas.  The contents were also overcooked, and one of the dishes was not something that we had ordered, it was a mistake?  The potatoes on one of the dishes were like little grayish cardboard bits with burned edges, while my salad was inedible.  I have never met a salad I didn't like, until today - wilted, strange lettuce, unripe tomatoes, accompanied by some horrible, beige "dressing" that didn't know if it was mayonnaise or sweetened sewage.
10$ per dish - so glad i threw my money away - we ditched and got breakfast round 2 elsewhere.  NEVER AGAIN.
The girls at the counter were friendly and efficient.  This rating is for the overpriced garbage food served, not the service.
author: CC C.

description: Discovered this on Yelp.  In the city last week and the wife and I looking for a hearty and healthy breakfast.  Tired of La Boulange every day.  Wow, what a great menu on the wall.  Just about everything you could want for breakfast or lunch!  Ordered at the counter, prices were reasonable.  Took our number and sat down.  Food was out quickly and delicious!  I can see they crank.  Not a lot of tables, always busy but we never had a problem getting a table.  Food was healthy and exceptional.  Made it there three times.  See you next trip.
author: Dan V.

description: Great food and close to our hotel. This was a great Yelp find for us! Stopped in here and was pleasantly surprised with the wide variety of food options and the freshness of this place. Items are about $10 each, some a little more. Our party had the 2-2-2, the Salsa crepe, an the Eggs Benedict and everyone was very pleases. We stay at our timeshare, the Donatello frequently so we definitely be back!
author: R C.

description: Used to come here as a kid and loved it. Went back and nothing has changed. Nice people and awesome food. I am a huge fan of the fettuccine with mushrooms and alfredo! WAYYYYYY better then italian places down the street! Can't wait to go back.
author: Kyla K.

description: This place was close to my hotel so we decided to check it out. There was a long line! I think my husband was in line for at least 25 minutes! And the line was out the door when we left! They have a full breakfast and lunch menu. They also have a full crepe menu. We both got the French Toast and it was just ok. Not great at all. My husband got a crepe too which he normally loves, but it was over cooked and very crispy. Not sure I have ever had a crispy crepe before.  The orange juice was awesome! It was freshly squeezed out of a huge machine. Yum!  Overall the food was just ok.
author: Debbi C.

description: Had the Apple crepe with whipped cream for breakfast. The crepe was pretty good but the whipped cream really made it tasty.  Side of bacon was just ok. Husband got potatoes as a side and they were really great!  Fast service once you order your food.
author: Caitlin H.

description:
40 minutes and still no food?  Seriously it's just not that complicated folks.  Soup is average and not hot enough (ironic given the ridiculous wait), Mediterranean crepe was above average, as was the rest of the meal.  

I've waited a long time for meals and found the food to be more than worth it...not this place.  Not today,  not ever.  

If you see a line, move on.
author: Michael M.

description: Food and the service were wonderful.  We had a difficult time choosing what to have for breakfast because everything looked good.
author: Jolene G.

description:
Pros: The orange juice tasted really good they have a juicing machine right behind the counter. The Belgian waffle with fruit was soooooo bomb I loved it would go back and get another one for sure. I need to go back and maybe try some other items on the menu.

Cons: Ok so first off the place could definitely use some cleaning up. The fresh squeezed oj was a little over priced in my opinion, $3.50 for a small glass of oj is pushing it, everything else was very reasonable. My bacon was cold.
author: Monica R.

description: Honey Honey was fun and delicious! The menu boards are clear and concise, and the staff are polite and helpful. I had a savory crepe, which had herbs mixed into the crepe itself. It was perfectly portioned. My bf had the tofu scramble, which I tasted and liked, but he felt that his home version was better...can't please everyone! Honey Honey is definitely worth a try!
author: Tiffany B.

description: Always a line! Cause it's gooood Try the Nutella crepe with banana and strawberries and eggs Benedict! Delicious
author: Nura M.

description: Great little breakfast place. Chill atmosphere, good food, nice staff and reasonable prices. Good veggie options too!
author: Kim M.

description: Nice little place with indoor and outdoor seating. Their egg Benedict and crab cake florentine, I highly recommend. The orange juice is squeezed in front you and I must say tastes so good. The strawberry and Nutella creeps for dessert is delish. The servings are huge too. The service is fast so don't get discouraged by the long line.
author: J L.

description: Someone tell this place that when you say you're open til 10, it means you're actually still serving customers until 10. I just tried getting a crepe at 9:36, and the guy at the counter briskly tells us they're closed. As we tried to say we thought they were open til 10, he mutters "kitchen closes early, kitchen closes early" and walks away from us. What happened to some damn politeness in the service industry, and what happened to actually being open during your claimed business hours? I'm crepeless and pissed.
author: Sophie P.

description:
This place was pretty bomb-diggity after a day of wandering around the city with J.
I'd be hard pressed to tell you whether the four stars were for the food or for the fact that it felt just that good to sit down for a minute.
But the food was quite delightful. 
I had the crabcake sandwich and J. had the salmon sandwich. Both were quite tasty and so incredibly satisfying. The potatoes they came with were decent but nothing to write home about.
We had a strawberry, banana, kiwi crep to split which was decent, but not the best I ever had. The crep itself was pretty thick for a crep, but the ice cream side was really good.
The salads looked ginormously amazing so I'm down to try it again.
author: Allison T.

description: Delicious Italian sodas, sandwiches, and crepes. The sandwiches in particular are scrumptious; I had the Venetian which was on special, but it was a delight! The blintzes had just the right amount of "pow" on them, and the italian sodas were as they should be. I went with my mother and sister and they both had a good time, although my mom was disappointed with the Chai which she called "too milky". We had to agree. All in all, a pretty solid brunch/lunch/breakfast joint.
author: Katrina R.

description:
The morning I checked out of my hostel as I was going to head back down to San Jose for the day before my flight home, I wanted to grab some breakfast nearby.  This place seemed to get some pretty decent ratings and was less than 2 blocks away, and had a low price point, so off I went.

The place itself seemed to have a little bit of a latin influence.  Not screaming, but "a little".  It was pretty spacious and couple probably seat close to 60-70 people.

They had a large chalkboard menu up on the near wall.  I eventually decided on the eggs benedict.  I went up to the counter to order.  I also ordered a glass of fresh squeezed (machine) orange juice.  The people there were nice enough.

I sat down with my orange juice and within a few minutes, my food came out.  It looked ok.  The side of home fries looked like were left sitting on the griddle for too long and were kind of charred.  Well, let's just say "extra crispy".  The hollandaise, canadian bacon, and muffin were fine, but the eggs were undercooked.  I mean, I love me some runny egg yolks.  Perfect for steak and eggs, but slightly underdone egg whites?  Not that I was worried about salmonella poisoning or whatever, it's just unappealing.

The potatoes were only as good as they looked.  Lacked flavor and underseasoned.  Just underwhelming.

Maybe I just got the wrong thing.  If I happen to be really close by, I'm not sure I'm coming back.
author: Austin S.

description:
Yelp, you have TOTALLY failed me by giving this place 4-stars. Four?! You are FAR too generous, Yelpers. 

First of all, for those who are not going to read this whole review: track down a Crepevine in SF and go there instead. Their menu is almost identical, but Crepevine's food is worth eating. 

We ordered coffees, a scramble (tofu), and a savory crepe (New Orleans). 

The coffee was total Folgers crap. I swear it had no flavor and a single drop of half & half turned it white as snow. 

Next, the tofu scramble could have been better assembled by 4th graders. It had eggs, smoked tofu, bell peppers, onions, and parsley. I can't imagine a more flavorless assemblance of ingredients, but something that seemed incredibly promising was nearly inedible in reality. The potatoes were OK, but rather bland. My english muffin wasn't toasted-- just plopped on the plate. 

Finally, my New Orleans crepe had rubbery, stinky chicken, raw mushrooms (not sauteed?!?), clumps of sundried tomatoes, and a ton of Swiss cheese. The cheese was a little overpowering, but thank goodness for the bounty of it because it was the only tasty thing in the crepe! The crepe itself was more of a pancake; it was thick and sweet. Imagine some thinned out Bisquick spread into a crepe. That was the crepe. It also came with the potatoes mentioned above. 

Overall, their menu looks promising. It looks like they took their time putting it together. However, it's their actual FOOD that they need to take some time in putting it together. So many of these problems could have been fixed by a somewhat talented cook.
author: Lindsey A.

description: Cute spot. Ordered breakfast burrito with no meat and a crepe. The cashier messed up our ordered by failing to write the no meat request. I was very angry. Thr owner immediately corrected the mistake and gave us delicious dessert on the house. Overall good food and service but attention to detail of a special request was missed.
author: Nurit Z.

description:
I was walking down Post St. looking for breakfast and strolled right in. It has a casual atmosphere, and the service is very friendly and cafe-style. You have to seat yourself but when I went there was plenty of space---weekends I've heard are more problematic. It's laid back, and I noticed the menu bears a striking resemblance to that of Crepevine.

I tried the Belgian waffles and found the portion a little overwhelming. It's really filling, no flour-skimping on these waffles. I also tried the house potatoes (delicious, perfect for breakfast) and the poached eggs which were very good. I'll update this review once I come back and try more things, but highly recommend the eggs.
author: Charles C.

description:
This small cafe is very conveniently located for travelers staying in hotels in the Union Square area. I visited for breakfast, after spending my first morning in San Francisco at Dottie's True Blue Cafe. Unlike Dottie's, I was the only person waiting outside the cafe when they opened at 7:30am! If you don't want to risk a wait, Honey Honey Cafe & Crepery is a much safer bet. 

While it was gray and raining when I visited, I think the cafe would be absolutely beautiful on a sunny day. I sat in the center of the cafe on a circular bench around a tile pillar that had tables arranged around it - a nice way to have a sense of a communal breakfast without actually having to talk to anyone before you've had your coffee!

When I visited, there were only two employees - the cashier/waitress and the cook. It was not super-crowded, but service was slow and I got the impression that she was annoyed with me for being waiting when the cafe opened. You order your food at the register then bring a number to your table - it can be difficult to juggle coffee/silverware/juice/water/whatever and the setup of the front counter was somewhat awkward. 

I wish I had tried one of the crepes, because my neighbors' breakfasts looked delicious! I was feeling somewhat rushed as - like I said, the cashier did not seem so thrilled that I was waiting outside the door - and was a little confused upon entering (do I take a seat? are there menus? do I just go up and order?). The answers are: hang out and look at the giant menu on the wall, the giant menu is on the wall, and yes - once you've figured out what you want to eat.  There's a lot on offer so it might take you a while! I ended up having a breakfast sandwich on a croissant with potatoes, and while it was nothing special, it was a good breakfast for a reasonable price.
author: Laura S.

description:
What the heck I haven't written a review?

I work across the street and school is a block away from here so I'm all about this place. Everything is pretty much under 10 bucks. And everything I've had here is BOMB

Tea is by the pot. Bagels are always yummy. Breakfast burrito is always perfect- not too eggy which is how I like it. I am a fan of their cheeseburgers. It isnt the best one i've had in my whole life but it fills me up and they hook it up with extra pickles. 

The crepes. So yummy. I am in love with the banana crepe. Add some ice cream and your good to go.

The flavored water is perfect on nice sunny days.

A good amount of out door seating. 

All in all- this place has it all and I'm all about it!
author: Amanda S.

description:
Stopped in for a quick lunch after shopping in Union Square and was pleasantly surprised by the large selection on the menu. There were savory and sweet crepes, sandwiches, pastas, salads, and breakfast foods. I settled on the North Beach crepe with chicken, mushrooms, onions, spinach, and swiss cheese. I recommend getting the Hollandaise sauce on the side, as the crepe by itself was rich and tasty enough with all the cheese. The chicken was tender and had some kind of cajun seasoning - it was a winner with the mushrooms. I liked how my crepe wasn't soggy, as it often is at other places I've been. My dining companion had the chicken pesto crepe, which was good, but nothing to write home about. Savory crepes come with a choice of salad, fruit, or potatoes, and are all around $7-10.

The restaurant itself was cute and laid back. You walk in and there's a huge chalkboard menu you can peruse before you order at the counter and find a table. It was pretty empty at 1:30 on a weekday, and our food came out fairly quickly. I liked the flavored water, and there's free wifi too. It would be a great place for a quick weekday lunch, or just to sit and work on your laptop.
author: Emily C.

description: I noticed in my nutella crepes that most of the nutella was in the middle.  It was not spread thoroughly.  The taste was okay, but I had better in IHOP.  I expected more from this place.  If you want to use your credit card, it has to be a five-dollar minimum.
author: Carlene R.

description: Came here for breakfast while I was staying around the block on a business trip. It was a quick but delicious meal of salmon eggs Benedict and iced coffee. Food and quality was good, wish I had stayed in town loner to try their crepes and other items on their menu.
author: Layla R.

description: Do not expect great service!! The food was good. We ordered the blintz and it took forever because they forgot about our order. Staff does not do anything to provide good customer service.
author: Erika Q.

description:
Before I came to Honey Honey, I'd never had a savory crepe. I know, I'm a heathen. But I came here and (despite the delicious-looking french toast) got a breakfast crepe. It wasn't a life-changing experience - in fact, the cheese wasn't quite melted enough, and the bell peppers could have been more finely diced. But I think I get the idea behind the dish now, and I like it.

I came in the next week and got the french toast, and it was better than the crepe was. Some of the better french toast I've ever had, actually.

The restaurant itself is pretty crazy-busy, especially around breakfast time on the weekends. You get in and order at the counter, then try to find a table. Emphasis on the try; I had to wait a while before a table opened up. Unfortunately, there's not much designed for singles (no diner-style eating counter here), so I felt kind of bad taking up a two-person table in the crowded restaurant. Oh well, I'm a speedy eater.

Prices are pretty steep (especially for beverages; why is there nowhere in this city where I can get a glass of orange juice with breakfast for under three dollars?), but everything looked at least passable, and most of the food I saw around me looked positively delicious. I think I'll head back for dinner at some point, because their non-breakfast menus also looked delicious.
author: James B.

description: It's not mind-blowing crepery magic but this could be my fault because I didn't realize the full menu was on the wall-ceiling area above the booths so I was limited to ordering from the special daily menu. Note to self: look up.
author: Julie K.

description: Love this place anytime I visit the city.  Tasty crepes. Creative omelettes. Great value whether for a snack, breakfast, or dinner.
author: Thomas M.

description: The food here was delicious. Very filling but not too heavy. I had the Florentine crepe which had cheddar, spinach, cottage cheese and onions. My husband had the Sunrise burrito (onions, salsa, chorizo, cheddar and eggs) served on black beans with cilantro. We shared the famous fresh squeezed orange juice which was perfectly naturally sweet. The atmosphere is inviting and warm with colorful walls and tables. Would definitely recommend to anyone.
author: Chanelle C.

description:
THE GOOD: the interior of the restaurant, free wi-fi, the complimentary orange or cucumber flavored water, the sweet crepes (but not crave-able)

THE DISAPPOINT: I don't like the idea of outdoor seating in the downtown area of SF. But the restaurant was crowded for brunch on Saturday, so we ended up breathing in a ton of exhaust with the food (really don't remember what I ate). That was the first time I was there. 

This past Monday--can't believe I decided to go a second time. This time I got indoor seating; I ordered the Mediterranean crepe. Sounds good, right? No. This thing tastes like a poorly made combo pizza (cheddar, onion, tomato, feta, artichoke, olives, avocado). Ugh... 

Savory crepes can be really good. Honey Honey just needs to work on their flavoring a bit more--I suggest some seasoning or marinating of the ingredients.
author: Joyce L.

description:
Honey Honey was pretty cute, decently priced.

Post St Omelet- Pretty good omelette, not special, the potatoes were super good though, had a lot of savory flavor going on there. Well seasoned. Right amount of that tasty crisp. 

Coffee was standard.

Super busy in the morning, this is a place to just bring one other person, didn't take too long to make once we were done ordering in the 20 person line.
author: Steven H.

description:
Stopped in for breakfast with a co-worker while on a business trip.

Food: 4/5-very tasty breakfast (especially liked the bacon).

Atmosphere: 4/5- typical SF crowd. Although I could have done without the pot smoke wafting through the doorway from the teenagers outside. But, it's San Fran!

Service: 2/5- when I requested to get the pecan pancakes with the two/two/two, the young gal at the counter snapped "NO". I waited thinking she was joking only to be told to hurry up and decide. There was no line behind my co-worker and I, so I'm not sure what the rush might have been. I simply cancelled my order and ordered two pecan pancakes, two bacon and two eggs. She seemed frustrated that I found a way around her attitude, slammed down the receipt and said "sign this", and then went about her business of ignoring people.

I am sure to return, simply because of the food and the crowd. But that snotty register gal needs to go...
author: Don J.

description: I couldn't tell you how the food is because we've been waiting 30 min to order. The problem? There is only 1 person to man the register and make the espresso drinks. Not that they're understaffed. There are twice as many people waiting to order as there are sitting in the dining room, so a busboy took the order of the guy behind us bc he was ordering to go. The guy who got his food when we were 3rd in line had already eaten by the time we ordered. Don't come here on a weekend if you will be hungry in the next 7 days.
author: Claire L.

description:
I ordered Egg Florentine and Fresh Orange Juice.

OJ was really fresh but Egg Florentine from this cafe is the worst in my life!!
Spinach was too boiled and English Muffin in the Bottom was soggy.
I left 2/3 of Egg Florentines.
author: Sara I.

description: Came here for breakfast from the recommendation of a dear friend and was not disappointed! My classic cheese and onion crepe was delicious, the side potatoes were well seasoned and so crispy, and my iced chai was absolutely delightful. The place was busy with a line but not over crowded - we had a cozy table and a short wait for our food! We'll definitely be back on our next visit!
author: Jessi L.

description: The past couple of times I have come to SF I have eaten here almost daily.  I really love their crepes...the savory crepes are good for any meal.  I really like the New Orleans.  If you are in the area, check it out.
author: Matt J.

description: the food was mediocre once we got it. the 2 of us spent a total of 50 bucks to wait almost an hour after being skipped for larger parties twice. the mimosas tasted awful and it was so overcrowded it was uncomfortable to eat in there. the upside were the potatoes and that's about it. servers were kind, manager was rude. will never return
author: Briana W.

description: Went here our first day of vacation is SF, and we ending up having breakfast here EVERY DAY until we left. So that should say something. The line was out the door and we almost decided to go to a different place at that point. But we figured there was a line for a reason, and we had to try it out. First off, the fresh squeezed orange juice!!!! Just thinking about it makes my mouth water. Best I've ever had, and I've had fresh squeezed OJ many times. The menu is huge and I especially love any breakfast foods with a Mexican twist, which they had plenty of. Mexican salad was delicious, waffles were amazing, crepes were great. And the girl who took our order every day always recognized us and was SO sweet and accommodating- I believe her name was Lana. I hope that's correct, as I'm horrible with names, sorry! But we will most definitely be back during our next trip to SF. Thank you, Honey Honey!!!
author: Jerilyn N.

description:
You only need to know 2 things about this restaurant: 

1. fresh fresh fresh squeezed OJ. They have the machine murdering oranges right in front of you. Yum. 

2. Strawberry/Nutella Crepe with whipped cream. I could not believe how much melty, chocolaty Nutella they crammed into this thing. SOOOO good... so sweet, such a stomach ache and a cavity. So worth it.
author: Jessica M.

description:
My wife and I stopped in here for a late breakfast.  We had walked past it a few times on our last visit, so we figured we'd give it a shot.  Although their menu is quite expansive for a smaller joint, I had a certain item in mind that wasn't listed.  Gratefully, the hospitiable folks there didn't scoff at my request for a burrito containing only cheese, potatos and bacon and were able to accomodate my picky eating.

Although the potatoes were undercooked (by, at least, 5 minutes) my signature burrito still tasted fresh and hit the spot on a chilly morning.  My wife enjoyed some Apple Crepes as well.

Over all, not a bad joint.  If I'm ever in SF again I will certainly return, perhaps for lunch this time.
author: Morgan M.

description:
I have been here a couple times and I always liked my experience at casual spot. There is an expansive menu to choose from (and yes, you can order a sandwich for breakfast here). I went here yesterday and I had the Chicken Pesto crepe ($8.50). It was an average sized crepe folded over but it was delicious. Lots of chicken, oozing with cheese with pesto and tomatoes in between. I opted for the fresh fruit as a part of the order, which was indeed fresh. I tried some of my friend's potatoes and they were good. Tabasco is on hand to make it spicy! Good Bloody Marys ($4.50) here as well.

Only a few problems with this place. If it's packed, it takes a while for the line to move. At least the food comes within 10-15 minutes. Second, check to make sure that the cashier understands your order correctly. One of my friends ordered a tofu sandwich, waiters gave him the same sandwich, but with tuna! He told this to a passing waiter and they apologized and brought out the correct dish within 5 minutes. 

Overall it's a great casual breakfast/lunch cafe a few blocks from Union Square/Nob Hill.
author: Phil H.

description:
It was Valentines day and my honey and I were trying to visit "the hundreds" only they didnt open until 12. Being extremely sore in the legs from the 10k run we did the previous morning, and VERY HUNGRY..my fooditude was started to kick in. I was fighting it as best as I could because after all it was valentines day.. 

To my surprise I turned around and there it was.. "Honey Honey Cafe" It was like a big white light shined down from the heavens above and BAM.. eggs benedict,crepes, MEMOMOSAS! all in one location. We wandered in correction: BEFORE wandering in.. he told me to look up this place on my Yelp app.. as I was busting out my phone he quickly said nevermind because they had the "people on YELP! love us" sticker.. so we walked in and they had ALL kinds of items.. I was strictly there for the eggs benedict and memosas.. I ordered 3 memosas because I didnt wanna get back in line.. I was gunnin for 4 but patrick only wanted 1 and well i knew I needed 2 ahaha.. the food was really good ESPECIALLy the potatoes.. such a wonderful place.. if your in the TL.. please check it out. .
author: Valerie G.

description:
Changing your name and getting a new paint job does not make it a new or a better restaurant. This is like the one establishment in the neighborhood that i refuse to eat at because it is so god-awful. i can't believe everyone else is enthusiastic about it.

the people in the kitchen don't know what the hell they're doing. this place is a fucking crepery. i'd expect that the actual crepe itself turned out like it was supposed to, fillings and other stuff aside. but no. not only is the crepe limp and boring, the filling is generally a sopping mess of not-so-fresh ingredients, and is sometimes even misleading (such as the case of the crab cake). 

Also, great that this restaurant has a huge menu. But what's the point? It all comes out burnt, bland, or dry.

Skip this place and go to J-town if you want to wait in line forever. At least there you'll get a good crepe.
author: Y K.

description:
Honey Honey is one of those places I have walked by many a time without trying it.  I finally gave it a try, ordering the roasted eggplant sandwich on baguette.  The baguette wasn't what I expected, it was larger and fluffier than a typical french baguette, but it was still good.  I enjoyed the sandwich, which comes with your choice of salad, fruit or potatoes.  I went with fruit, which was a meager serving of a banana sliced up, one strawberry sliced up, and a single kiwi slice on top.  Oh, and like 1/8 of an apple thinly sliced.  Stick with the side salad.

I also ordered mint tea, which is served by the pot (and costs 2.50).  The tea was ok, but I liked that they gave me a lot and steamed the mug.

And to finish the meal I bought one of their oatmeal raisin cookies, $1.50 for a pretty small cookie and it was not good at all.  Avoid! 

Overall I liked the sandwich but everything here seemed pretty overpriced (sandwich was like $8).  It would be one thing if it was amazing food, but it's not.  

On the plus side, entree portions seem to be generous and there is a nice variety of foods to be had, so it will be worth a return visit to try the crepes and/or breakfast foods.
author: Joseph N.

description:
My dinning experience at Honey Honey was my worst dinning experience in San Francisco.  

-1 Star for having customers shuffle dirty plates around to make room to sit.

-1 Star for extremely slow service.

-3 Stars for overall bad food.  I ordered the Half Moon Bay, crab crepe which came EXTREMELY well done.  The crab was beyond burnt, more cheese than any person can ask for, and the crepe it self was  over cooked.

Never have I had food from a restaurant burnt that bad.  If I ever return I won't be ordering food.
author: Jon T.

description:
The food is awful. 
I don't know why this place has four stars! Maybe they  have a special dish????
 I was hopeful to enjoy this little cafe.
I understand liking the price point- but if the food is terrible who cares!
uck!
author: Sherri R.

description:
This is a review of the Mediterranean and Florentine vegetarian crepes.


My girlfriend and I stopped by here late at night trying to fill our crepe desires, but I must say we left feeling so unloved from eating here.

Now being vegetarians and crepe lovers, we had our expectations set by places like "Creme de la Crepe" in LA and "The Crepe House" on Washington and Polk. There are some fantastic vegetarian crepes out there, but the ones from Honey Honey were subpar.

The bad:

Our crepes were slightly burnt. Not brown burnt, but black around the edges burnt.

They both were loaded with too much cheddar cheese which just threw the balance off and after a few bites all you could taste was cheddar.

There was hardly any spinach in the Florentine, let alone few olives and artichokes in the Mediterranean.

The Potato wedges we received with both dishes were overcooked and if they weren't stale, then they really came close to it. I had to douse them in hot sauce to wet them down a bit.



The good: 

They do have some good green chili sauce. If you're displeased with your crepes, just take the tube and leave the standard tip. It'll be a compliment.


Seriously, go to another place for Vegetarian crepes.
author: Shaun D.

description:
This place was our morning hang-out for most of our family trip to San Francisco... 

Why? Well, not just because it was right up the street from our hotel and we are major lazy in the mornings...but, because it's unpretentious & reasonably friendly, it serves several varieties of our favorite breakfast (dessert crepes), it's lively & full of people, it had 4 stars on Yelp, and it serves a decent cup of coffe (and tea)! Send your fellow diners out on table reconnaissance as you order at the counter, grab your drinks, and wait for your delicious breakfast to materialize in front you...enjoy!
author: Janet D.

description:
What would I do without Yelp!? 

Thank you yelp for leading us to this awesome place after our volunteer shift at Glide Memorial last saturday. 

The menu is gigantor...literally! The menu wall is filled with goodies from breakfast to crepes to burgers. I decided on the crab florentine and a chai with a shot of espresso. The crab florentine was really tasty! I think that was the first time I've ever had a poached egg, and I dont really like em...but mmm the holandaise sauce and the crab...sooo good! Next time, I think I'll ask for my egg over hard. My meal came with potatoes which was a nice surprise, but it felt like someone went a little spice happy behind the counter...a little salty and over herby for me. The chai was spiced just right, and the shot of espresso added an extra kick. 

I can't wait to come back and try the delicious looking sweet crepes!
author: Trina A.

description:
i love this place! unlike Ricky Bobby i have no problem admitting that I LOVE CREPES. for all you baydestrians...you got purple...i got crepes!!!

so now you can see why i give this place 5 wonderful stars! 
the food here is great. ive had the strawberry banana nutella crepe, chicken pesto, and most recently the crab cake florentine! maybe i wasnt that hungry that day but the crab cakes werent my favorite. not that they were bad i just think it was an off day. every other time i get crepes here they are to die for!
author: Ashley H.

description: Charming brunch spot that overall was enjoyable. Friendly staff, fast service with a line that moved, and filling portions. 3/5 stars because of a very bitter cappuccino and their music selection, which was a total mismatch to the decor, people, and brunch vibe.
author: Daniel F.

description:
Omeletes and crepes a plentiful at this place. I would definitely recommend if you are in the area and want a reasonable breakfast and of course free wifi.

The menu is quite extensive so it can suit many.
author: Pilar M.

description:
There is a Yelp! sticker on the door indicating that many fellow Yelper's like this place.  I'm wondering why?  I've eaten here twice now.  Both times I've been underwhelmed by the food and "service" such as it is.

This morning I ordered pancakes.  There was an odd taste to some of the pancakes, as if the griddle hadn't been cleaned from whatever had been cooked there before, which detracted a lot from the pancake taste.  The smallest piece of butter topped the pancakes, prompting me to ask for more butter.  I was also annoyed that they were covered in powdered sugar.  I expect powdered sugar on french toast, not pancakes.  I know, I know, I'm being picky, but this is my review.  :)

You place your order at the front.  While I'm not expecting fast food speediness, how long does it take to assemble a pot of tea?  Almost 10 minutes seems excessive when the place isn't full.

I'd hoped that Honey Honey would better for breakfast than lunch since I wasn't that impressed with my lunch.  Sadly,  it's not good for either.
author: Scott S.

description:
This place is DISGUSTING!!  I can forgive BAD service.....and TACKY decor ...if the food is good. But this place has BAD service, TACKY decor...and the food is CRAP!
I knew we were in for trouble when I saw the cook in the back open a big plastic bag of pre-cubed and seasoned 'home fries' from Costco.  Too much trouble to peel potatoes, I guess..  I ordered the Cobb Salad.....my friend ordered a soup and sandwich. .....  When my Cobb was served....it looked OK.....a bit deconstructed with the greens tossed in dressing...and the chicken breast, avocado, and bacon on top.  The PROBLEM was the dressing....it was SUPER CHEAPO Ranch from a bottle, that tasted awful, and RUINED the salad.....also it was missing the crumbled bleu cheese, and the hard boiled egg.  My friends sandwich was on plain, sliced white bread, and the soup was not home made....and the 'home fries'  from a plastic bag were on his plate.  He said they were gross.....and 15 minutes later said what a bad aftertaste they left in his mouth.  It does not seem that Honey Honey makes ANYTHING from scratch.  I all seems to be Costco crap.....Save your money.  Go someplace that actually makes their food.  Everyone that is giving their Eggs Benedict such great reviews might want to make sure that it is being made from scratch.....and not from a can!
author: Bryan M.

description:
This place is disgusting. The coffee cup that they gave me had stains in it, looked like it hadn't even been washed and had crumbs on the rims. I didn't even bother to ask for another cup. This seems like a place that just doesn't care. It's not like their coffee was good either.

I ordered a blintz and I could have made a better tasting blintz. . I've never even made one. The skin of the crepe was too doughy, seems like it was almost uncooked and it had horrible consistency. The cream cheese inside was lumpy and overall it was very runny. 

Although the blintz looked good, don't let the pictures or the appearance fool you. 

The only reason I came in here was for the free wi-fi access. The waitress was nice so they get at least one additional star.
author: Gary Y.

description:
I really enjoy this place for breakfast - any time of the day. They have many options including savory or sweet crepes, omelettes and pancakes.  I've enjoyed everything I've ordered on my three trips.  I also noticed some more lunch-like options like sandwiches, though I have never tried them. 
Service was quick on a Saturday evening as the place was quite empty(apparently not EVERYONE shares my joy of breakfast-for-dinner), but I do recall weekend mornings being busy. It wasn't such an issue of a long wait for our food, just the 'where will I find a place to sit' stress. It wasn't a problem as I was just with a friend but if I had a larger group with me it would have concerned me.
author: Melanie I.

description:
This cafe & crepery enticed my friend and I to stop in for a hot latte and a dessert crepe post-dinner.  

So many things went wrong. First of all, this place was severely understaffed. Felt bad for the guy at the counter who had to handle the register and serve the dishes and clean up the tables. Which led to the second problem of trying to find a clean table to sit at that wasn't littered with dishes and trash from previous customers. 
Next, the latte wasn't hot or strong enough and was considerably expensive for the small cup it arrived in.  As for the strawberry and nutella crepe with whipped cream we ordered, it was unappetizing. There was little nutella to be found, but instead tons of chocolate sauce. And I'm not sure about anyone else, but I prefer my strawberries fresh in crepes, not cooked.  The crepe itself was bland and had a rubbery texture, perhaps overcooked?.  They couldn't even get the whipped cream right too, warm whipped cream?? No thanks...
author: Serena C.

description:
For what this is, it is about as good as it gets.  I had a Nutella and banana crepe with a side of vanilla ice cream and it was absolutely heavenly. 

The cucumber and lemon water they provide is both unique and refreshing. It was a great way to start the day!
author: Justin F.

description: Something more.  That's really what I need here: Honey Honey puts out an okay product, but slow service and a lack of punch hampers a good thing.  Definitely a place to check out for the breakfast timid, but I need chorizo to kick my ass, not tickle my tongue.
author: Michael D.

description: We were looking for an afternoon snack after shopping in Union square.  This place was nearby.  Our group of four tried a burger, a club sandwich, a savory crepe and a dessert crepe.  They were all excellent.  The atmosphere is relaxed and I can see this would be a great place to spend an afternoon with a laptop or a book. If I lived in the neighborhood this would definitely be on my regular hangout list.
author: Carron S.

description:
I make it a point to come here when I'm in town for work for two main reasons:

1) It's within walking distance from the Hotel Monaco.

2) It's a delicious and cheap way to stay within my per diem and enjoy a great meal. 

Their savory crepes never disappoint and my favorite is the half moon bay crepe. It comes potatoes, but since they tend to be dry I substitute curly fries. I wash it all down with a cold pint.  Recommend.
author: Javier F.

description: I have been here 10 times since moving to San Francisco proper. It's delicious. Sometimes I order two breakfasts, such as a Nutella banana crepe and an egg dish. The crepe comes with a side of whipped cream or ice cream. Yum. I'm not too sure why I am not giving this 5 stars, I guess I reserve that for something I really, really love, but it's definitely a 4.5 in my mind. Note that it is not full-service, you wait online to order and they bring the food to your table. There is some outdoor side-walk seating. {Minuses: it's located in Nob Hill on a hill, so if you don't like to or have a hard time walking, dining in Nob Hill probably isn't the best place for you.} Prices: $8/9-ish for entree. When I go there, I usually spend abut $15 on food and $3 for drinks.
author: Lauren H.

description:
The girl I had gone out with the night before told me we had to have breakfast here. Apparently it would help restore my energy and get the mojo flowing for a proper weekend. Crepes? I'm so in!

The menu on the wall reminded me of my favorite crepe spot in Paris. That alone awards a star on Yelp. I do prefer the casual counter ordering experience some days;  especially when I am nursing a slight hangover and just want to be quiet and at my own pace. 

I went with a strawberry crepe creation along with a healthy side of bacon. You need that fat to soak up the excess alcohol, or so I told myself! My lady friend went with an omelet which I deemed in poor taste considering my state. For whatever personal reason, I just can't make an omelet sound good on a queasy stomach. In any event our food was served up quickly and mine was absolutely fabulous. I won't comment on the omelet but my girl seemed to like it.

We held our quiet corner for a while in food consumption bliss. I have to say the price is right for this nice little gem in the city.
author: Nick B.

description: They have a great variety here, from crepes, to breakfast items such as my eggs benedict salmon (MMMM), desserts, lunch, literally a plethora of food choices, Kim L.(below) is very accurate with a description of this restaurant. It was crowded here on a Sunday morning and was worried about not able to sit down, but it's such a fast paced-environment that when we stood in line and finished ordering our food, we were able to get a seat right away. This is one of my favorite crepes place now, because of their menu variety! =]
author: Jojo N.

description:
ok, i'm giving a 3 star rating, but i'm really torn on that. part of me wants to give a 5, the other part of me wants to give a -4,000.

i've come to love the food, and i eat here often, but something is always wrong. either the service is lackluster or the order is wrong. i'm finding that anytime there is a possibility of an option given to the customer, this is where the problem will start. first, if asked would you like your meal cooked style A or style B, no matter what you choose, the counter person seems annoyed by your choice. not only that, you'll get the exact opposite of what they offered. eggs over easy? how about scrambled. bacon crispy? how about chewy? can i get avocado added? sure, we'll charge you for it, but you won't get it. 

i really do love the food when it's done right. obviously this place is owned by the same people that do Squat & Gobble. i've always loved the other locations and i was really happy to see this place so close to where i live. i just wish they could get it together.
author: Gary V.

description:
This place was pretty yummy!  The nice thing was that it met all of our needs - hubby wanted coffee & a bagel, I wanted a latte and a sitdown meal.  Tada!  Honey Honey fit the bill.

Its located RIGHT on the corner (the doors face the intersection).  The food was good - the crepes were a little on the thicker side...the latte was perfect as was the coffee & bagel.  Hubby liked the coffee and liked that it was refilled at your table.  

Only complaint?? It was really, really warm in there and the opera music was a little too loud for that early in the AM.
author: H G.

description:
Every time I try to go here, there's been a long line! I got lucky on Sunday after the NWM '12. Loved the whole menu on huge chalk board on one wall. Seating is limited since it gets so busy.

-Chorizo Egg Scramble
-Apple Crepe (not really sweet) I'll have to try the other types

It's very cute and casual in here. I like the vibe and plan on going back
author: Lola D.

description:
Yum! I came here with a big group (7 people) on a Sunday for brunch and we got seated quickly, they brought us the food quickly, and everyone liked what they got! The only complaint was that one person wished they had been more adventurous... because what a menu!

They have oodles of crepes. Pretty original ones, too. I got a pesto crepe which was delicious and so filling. I couldn't even finish it. It comes with a side, I got a salad which had a good dressing. My friends were pleased with their crepes too.

Quite a nice little find that we just happened upon!
author: Christina B.

description:
Stopped in here for breakfast on my last visit to the bay area with my daughters in tow.    I enjoyed the Torino crepe with feta cheese, basil, tomatoes and mushrooms and the breakfast potatoes.  Daughter #1 got the plain crepe with sugar and whipped cream and daughter #2 ordered scrambled eggs and bacon.  We all enjoyed our meals.   Very friendly staff. 

The restaurant was busy, but we found a seat fairly quick.  It was almost unbearably warm, which we attributed to our long walk to get there and needing to acclimate to the heating...however, by meal end, we were still overheated.  

Decided to come back the next day to pick up breakfast and take it back to the hotel room.  Torino again for me (what can I say...it was good), waffles and pancakes for the kids. The order was exactly as we asked and included all the fixings (napkins, forks, condiments, etc.).  Tasty once more.

We will definitely return next time we are in town!  Thanks Honey Honey!
author: Wendy O.

description: Wow so busy when I came in to pick up an order, line from register to door. Any way, pretty good chorizo scramble and salmon Benedict. Would go back at night for breakfast or order take out. I despise long lines. People in general.
author: Kasey H.

description:
Such a cute cafe! So colorful and I found it in an instant cause it's in the corner and it's so bright! Hah.

Stopped by here yesterday and my cousin and I got the Florentine crepe and Belgian waffle. It was yummy!  When you walk in, you see this humungo menu and I was def. overwhelmed! Not overwhelming like the cheesecake factory menu but still. Lots of options.  I wanted EVERYTHING! Hah. There were water pitcher thingys? by the register that had orange in the water and one with lemon.  Very cute! 

We sat down in these cutely design tables and such and waited for our food. Yum! Everything came and oh my gosh..the florentine  crepe with the potatos (oh, crepes come with fruit, potatoes and something else) and our waffle. My cousin and I dug in and the crepe was very light and fluffy.  The savory filling was equally as delicious.  I'm a meat junky and this crepe had no meat in it and I was smitten with it.  The combination of the onions and spinach with the cheese is making my mouth water! Hah.  We finally finished it and my cousin and i looked at each other and realized we had waffles to eat. Oye, clutching our stomachs we start on the waffle and that was equally as delicious! It was topped with bananas and strawberries. Yummy!
author: Denise L.

description:
Belgium Waffles+ Eggs Benedict all up in my mouth. 

A gal pal and I split two dishes. The portions weren't bad, but the eggs were too runny. No bodily fluid jokes.  The potatoes were fantastic, as were the fluffy waffles topped with fresh fruit and whipped cream. 

During our meal, we stared at a boy (who was way too old and big) sitting on his father's lap for 20 minutes. Seeing the two, blurred the line of being hilarious and illegal (hilariously illegal?)  

Chomo jokes aside, I'd return to this place just for the taters and waffles.
author: Angie O.

description: Excellent little breakfast place. Huevos rancheros were good. It was very busy, but the man working there still took the time to check on us and ask about my order.
author: Tim R.

description:
For quality control purposes I have infiltrated this locality twice before reviewing. To enumerate:

1. The breakfast crepe. Heavy, American, generously portioned, satisfying. Great breakfast potatoes with it. Cheddar a little gooey but I like it that way. (I just might be the kind of reprehensible philistine who slathers--lightly, mind you--a fair percentage of their omelettes and omeletteish foods with ketchup for flavor. So caveat lector.)

2. The strawberry desert crepe. Light and just the right amount of sweet. Good whipped cream, possibly made in house.

3. Non-comestible factors. Actually I was surprised at the feel of the place, it's a little bit, I don't know...off. Service is okay but one time I had to really put some effort into attracting attention to myself so I could order at the counter, even though I was the only person in the restaurant. There is free wifi (protip: take one of their business cards when you order and the fax number is the network password) but it didn't work for me. Sad face.

Good kind of place to have in your neighborhood. I may come from time to time.
author: Peter B.

description: It was really crowded and I wasn't sure what to expect really, but their Chorizo egg scramble and their home fries are some of the tastiest I've ever had.
author: M M.

description:
Just tried this place for the first time and was excited based on previous reviews. However, I won't be going back.

The food that we ordered just wasn't very good. Maybe we should have ordered something else. My wife had the belgian waffle, and although it came with a perfect balance of fresh strawberries, bananas, and whipped cream, the waffle itself was slightly burnt and tough to chew. I had the crepe suzette, and it too was overcooked and chewy. Also, the some of the orange zest still had the pith on it, so every other bite was bitter.

That said, the fresh orange juice is really spectacular, hence the two stars. I would come back here just to order a giant glass to-go!
author: Justin E.

description: Hit the spot.  Fresh squeezed OJ, banana nutella crepe, Belgian waffle.  All amazingly good!
author: A B.

description: Waited forever and was served the chorizo scramble that was spoiled. It was taken away when asked and no refund. Highly overrated and ruined my day!
author: Pati F.

description:
This is the best café in San Francisco!
We stayed at the USA Hostel on the next block, and Honey Honey was the best finding ever. I especially recommend it for breakfast and brunch--there's a lot of variety from the menu, and the crepes are great. Despite the very generous servings, it still feels like you're eating the healthiest breakfast, since the ingredients are so fresh and the food tastes very homey, made with love. The service is great too--the owners recognized us after the first day (we had breakfast there for our entire 1-week stay in SF) and were so nice with us :)
My favorite was the florentine crepe and the crab cake benedict sandwich.  We didn't get to try their waffles, but the neighbour's looked tasty!
Their coffee, espresso, oj, and infused water are a pleasant surprise. 
We will definitely come back to have breakfast here every day on our next trip to San Francisco!!
author: Selene P.

description:
Had breakfast here with some friends from out of town this morning, and the food was really good!   There was a little bit of a line to wait through (with two young kids), but it moved pretty quickly and our food came out quickly as well.  

Both kids ordered pancakes--which were three HUGE pancakes.  They don't really have a kids' menu, so these were adult sized orders.  I tasted a bite of my son's pancake and loved them.  They're the texture I prefer--on the eggy side, somewhere between a typical pancake and a crepe.  My son, who is only four, ate all three pancakes, so I guess he liked them pretty well, too.  ;-) 

I had the breakfast crepe, which was delicious.  My only hesitation is that I would have gone a little lighter on the green pepper, maybe.  My husband got a salmon egg scramble and he said it was great.  One of the other adults in our party got a chicken breakfast burrito of some kind, which he seemed happy with, but it was so huge, I think he only ate half.

So...thumbs up on the food and the service (they brought food quickly, were good about clearing plates, etc.).   Prices seemed reasonable--not dirt cheap, but the portions were very generous.

We don't get up to the city for breakfast often, but I'm going to remember this place the next time we do....
author: M D.

description: Excellent food and decent prices; The place itself is extremely cramped, so dont be surprised if you have food and nowhere to sit. I'd definitely return.
author: Jordan A.

description:
"[Honey Honey,] you seem very well, things look peaceful. I'm not quite as well, I thought you should know..."

Fool me once, shame on you. Fool me twice, EFF YOU, Honey Honey! I wanted to like you, I really did. No, I wanted to love you. I wanted you to appease the beast within. I gave you a second chance (ordered a savory crepe). A breakfast crepe, to be exact. How could you serve me such bland garbage? My good ol' friend Tabasco couldn't save it! Need I say more? Well, okay, one more thing: what's up with that pre-packaged iceberg lettuce salad? You know, the kind with the shredded carrots and red cabbage...the kind you can get a pound of for $3. I guess it was a perfect match for that nasty and unidentifiable dressing. 

Can you feel my woman's scowl burning into your soul every time I pass you on my walk home? "Well, can you feel it?!? I thought that you, you, you oughta know!!!"
author: Kristine W.

description: We went to farm:table and couldn't see waiting an hour for a seat or food (and got there at 9:10 am, it opens at 9), so we backtracked to Honey Honey.  It's ok.  Decent selection of sweet and savory crepes, omelettes, sandwiches.  I didn't think the food was great but it did come quickly.  My omelette with basil and tomato was decent, the potatoes on the side were greasy and both too herbacious but not salty enough.  My side of bacon was really limp.  My sister's side of sausage was sweet, which had we known, she wouldn't have ordered it.  Blech, who likes sweet sausage?  Eggs Benedict sauce was slightly curdled and runny at the same time. The crepes looked better but we didn't want the equivalent of candy for breakfast.  It's very warm in there, and very crowded.  It could use a good scrubbing, it all seems a bit sticky and dingy, and I didn't like the fruit flies buzzing around.  It's perfectly fine for what it is but I wouldn't go back again.
author: Rebecca H.

description: Delicious crepes, empty place except for us. Water tasted strange.  Got miami heat crepe. Would get again
author: Torrance C.

description: Great breakfasts, forget the service, you are not there for that!  Do the benedict or Feds with chicken apple sausage.  Not greasy, good coffee, I'll be back!
author: Jon B.

description:
I go here for brunch, lunch, or dinner once in a while. Usually I bring people from out of town or large groups of friends with me. Prices are reasonable, food is good, and the dining room is adequate. 

Sometimes the tall man that seems to run or own the place is a little "snappy" at his lady staff. That's about the only thing that I feel stops it from getting 5 stars.
author: Matt C.

description: Tried the strawberry & nutella crepe. Quite tasty. The crepe with tomato, pesto, pine nuts, spinach and cheddar was amazing! Good coffee too.
author: Karen S.

description: eh just an over all bad time. it took them like 25 minutes to make a salad and a sandwich and we were 2 of about 6 total people in there. I got a tuna salad with red leaf lettuce. well my lettuce was green and brown. YUCKKKK
author: Opi T.

description: Solid food, if a bit pricey. The crepes are a bit overstuffed and none-too-delicate as crepes go. It's all tasty though, and they have a wide ranging menu for all tastes from sweet to savory.
author: Terry G.

description: Great selections with good tasting breakfasts; omelettes, crepes, waffles, french toast, pancakes, & specials. (Only tired breakfast so far)...
author: Brandon E.

description:
This place makes my tummy happy!  It's actually only a 2.5 but the extra little dose of happy takes it over the edge.  

Pesto Crepe.  That's it, never looking back.

The breakfast potatoes are terrible (and this is coming from a girl who hasn't met a carb she didn't like).  The service is a bit slow.  Sometimes I'd really like a glass of water without the taste of fruit.  Just plain, cold water.

The Pesto Crepe won me over though and I'm happy to go back for that!  Wonder if I'll ever convince myself to try something new....
author: Melissa Q.

description: Very friendly staff working hard delivering one of the best chicken pesto crepes in SF. Brunch, here I come.
author: Ivan B.

description:
The first time I stumbled upon Honey Honey, I was offered a free cup of coffee because I walked in with my own. It's a cute little policy they have although the coffee is not what I went for.....obviously.

I love love love neighborhood restaurants! I can't imagine driving here since the street parking is so bad. I don't even remember what I ordered but it was some kind of vegetarian crepe. There is nothing wrong with it, maybe it was just too average to give them more stars. 

When its a nice day, you can sit outside and smoke ciggs after you stuff your face.
author: emily g.

description: MUST TRY THIS PLACE!! We were not disappointed with this place AT ALL. The food is plenty! Crepes are delicious! But do get there before 9a and "spot" a seat/s while you're in line, it gets crowed quickly!
author: Corinne S.

description: We all enjoyed our breakfast.  Great fresh squeezed OJ.  Very good breakfast food.  I only gave 3 stars, not 4 because I,d rather table service to cafeteria style, but if its all about the food, come here.
author: Craig R.

description:
For me, the true test of a breakfast spot is if the cook can make you an over-medium egg. Not an easy thing to do and most cooks can't be bothered with it. Honey honey gave me over-easy without any toast to soak it up with. 2 strips of bacon...kind of skimpy, don't ya think?

The wife's waffle was soggy...no crunch whatsoever.
author: Craig T.

description: They accommodated me and my dietary restrictions by serving me just three poached eggs and whole bunch of sautéed spinach. Tasted pretty good (although poached eggs were a little overdone) and all for only $5.15. Great price for the area. I'd come back here.
author: Jill C.

description: Another nice little cafe offering good service and free WIFI.  I had the Venice sandwich on sourdough and (of course) a coffee.  Although I didn't see it on the menu, the sandwich came with pan fried potatoes, which were nice and crispy, but not greasy at all.  The food was super-fresh and was the perfect little lunch.
author: Troy S.

description: Savory breakfast crepes were not great.  All the reviews I read had me so excited and it's the first time yelp didn't pull through.  I believe it's under new management or new chef because my experience was meh.
author: Courtney R.

description:
There was a long line for sunday breakfast/brunch but I would wait in line again to eat there because the food was that good.  The Breakfast crepe was delicious.  Seeing others eating the eggs Benedict with the sauce dripping over the edge made me want some sort of sauce on the crepe, so a little bowl of salsa fixed it right up.

Friendly and helpful wait staff as well.
author: C B.

description:
Sometimes I have a strong and persistent craving for breakfast/brunch foods. I had one of those cravings about a week ago. Where did I want to go to satisfy this need? Squat and Gobble. I like squat because it's good and it's a nice place to hang out and just talk. Food there is good, but nothing to DIE for.

I'm glad I wasn't able to go there that day after all. 

My friend that I was meeting up for lunch was not anywhere near squat and gobble, and it was just more convenient to get lunch near the area she was around. I was disappointed at first, but that disappointment didn't last long. She suggested honey honey, and I said, "fine".

Driving around that area was kind of a bitch. I've driven around that area many times, but it was still a bitch because drivers in and near downtown are just a bunch of impatient bitches. I finally parked around the restaurant. I was a bit frustrated from the terrible experience on the road, but I was more annoyed when I had to pay the parking meter. I live in the peninsula and I'm not accustomed to carrying tons of change intended for parking meters. I had enough for 15 minutes. That was annoying.

I walk inside and meet up my friend. "Wow", I say in my head, "it's pretty cute!". We order quickly so that I can get change to fill that meter again. I order the pesto crepe because the guy at the cashier recommended it. My friend got the salsa crepe. I also ordered a chocolate belgian waffle and a cup of coffee. The guy also gave me tons of quarters to pay the parking meter. I was happy :)

First sip of the coffee. "Damn!!!!!!", I'm thinking. Only in SF can you get some damned good coffee. Honey honey certainly has some serious good, bold but not too bold, slightly sweet, and aromatic coffee. 

My first impression of the crepe. Hmm, kinda small, but looks pretty, at least. First bite into the crepe, "FUCK", I think. It was absolutely delicious. Every ingredient was flavorful and fresh. I'm not kidding you. Crepevine aint got nothing on honey honey. 

First bite into that chocolate waffle. *OoOoOooOoOOo*, chocolate GOODNESS. I can't explain it. It was great. The warm, melted chocolate had taken over my taste buds and I was damn near nirvana, I gotta say.

After lunch, we chit chatted, drank some more coffee, and smoked a few cigarettes (outdoor seating available). I was no longer sore about the shitty experience driving around that area. I was also fine with needing to get quarters every 40 minutes to feed that meter. (even though my friend ran to the meter and inserted the quarters cuz i'm fuckin lazy) Honey Honey was well worth the minor annoyances of life :)

love honey honey!!!
author: Bonita C.

description:
No one's trying to reinvent the wheel here; Honey Honey boasts a smart collection of breakfast treats, from the challah bread french toast that I kept in the crosshairs to the varied selection of crepes and other morning fare errata that sounded perfect to my dining companion. 

Color me a philistine (or at least someone not regularly privy to fancy squeezing machines), but I got a kick out of watching the orange juice actually emerge from the oranges themselves. There's a warm and inviting (if not uber personal) vibe here, and our food arrived without a long wait. And now I have another go-to breakfast spot in San Francisco. That's always welcome.
author: Kevin N.

description: While visiting the city, in 2010, I had breakfast every morning at this cute little cafe. I had a different item each day, all of which were delicious.
author: Esther T.

description:
Free wi-fi, good food, yummy coffee, VERY laid-back environment.

The menu incorporates lots of fresh ingredients, and it is hard to resist all those yummy veggies. I got the crabcake florentine and it was good, but not great. Not too heavy on the sauce. Adam got a breakfast sandwich, it was HUGE, and tasty. 

We both got coffees, they were hot and yummy. I decided on a little sugary goodness and got a dollop (a LARGE dollop) of whipped cream.

The environment was very laid back, and I saw a lot of diners either studying, reading, or on their laptops. It seemed like a good place to get work done.

Overall, laid back environment, tasty (but not great) food, gooood coffee, and nice staff. 

If I ever move back to SF, I'm going to LIVE here.
author: Kaiulani K.

description: Decent breakfast... My husbands chorizo eggs were good. My breakfast crepe was just okay.
author: Jessica P.

description:
Ate breakfast twice at Honey Honey based on the concierge's referral.  Good and quick.  I had the ham & cheese croissant, which was great and I would definitely order again.  Boyfriend had the banana and pecan pancakes, also good, but not iHop, you only get 2 pancakes.  The second day I choose the chicken pesto crepe, which was delicious.  Bf had the banana and nutella crepe.

Great crepe selection!  yum!
author: Danielle T.

description:
I think I like the IDEA of Honey Honey more than I like the actual establishment.

I've been here a few times because it is close and convenient but each time I leave a little underwhelmed. They have an impressively extensive menu but they seem to lack the follow through.

I got the smoked salmon and sour cream omelet  which was good but with waaaay too much sour cream.

There is always a long line when I have been there and sometimes you have to stalk other patrons to get a table.

Not a bad place but IMHO over hyped.
author: Nick E.

description: Amazing selection of foods and outstanding service. I ordered the pesto crepe with chicken and it was delicious. Do not miss out on this place if you are in SF! :) I come here EVERYTIME I'm in the city.
author: Adrienne-Marie P.

description:
Small, quaint, and to the point. 
The menu is artistically displayed in chalk on the wall. The only downfall to that is if you sit at the tables below the menu you will have people standing table side trying to read the menu while you are eating. 
The food is okay- nothing over the top but for $12.00 you can get breakfast and coffee, for Union Square that's a great price. 
The service is quick and friendly but not over the top. 
Compared to nearby cafes this one is at the top of my Union Square Cafe list.
author: Janell D.

description: Great food ....you order on at the counter but that's ok ....a great verity of food breakfast and lunch nice clean and quite loved it
author: Ruth C.

description:
Despite the long line to order at lunch time, it was a delicious experience worth waiting for.

If you are a brunch/breakfast food type of person, you'll most likely enjoy what this place has to offer. I got the Eggs Florentine - simple, clean, and none-over-the-top like many other places that try to make egg benedictions. The portions were also well off, more than enough for most individuals (considering the side of potato harsh that comes w/ most orders).

Also, the wait here is nothing compared to Mama's!
author: Ming S.

description: This is my go-to cafe when visiting here. It is open from early to late and everything is good. The crepes and omelettes are super tasty. It is fairly busy for breakfast and lunch but the line moves pretty well. Skip  the seafood offerings and go veggie. My favorites are Pesto, Milano, Athens, Miami Heat and Meditteranean.
author: Mark A.

description: I'm a huge breakfast snob, and Honey Honey Cafe got all of the important details right when it came to the food. I had the Eggs Florentine -- the eggs were cooked perfectly, and it was the perfect hangover cure. My boyfriend ordered the pesto crepe with pine nuts and said it was delicious. The only negative, and reason it's not 5 stars, is that it was too warm inside and crowded, and the outdoor seating was limited (only one table.) Since it was a nice day, once we were able to move to the outdoor table, I enjoyed this meal a lot more. If I'm ever in the area again, I'll be back. There are lots of other items on the menu I want to try.
author: Adena D.

description:
I ordered the crab cakes benedict.  When I received it, I noticed my "crab cakes" looked like fish sticks and I was skeptical about the "crab meat."  My boyfriend, I believe in an effort to prove me wrong, asked the guy at the counter what the crab cakes are made of, to which he received a blank stare, then the words, "imitation crabmeat."  

There is no reason a restaurant should have TWO crab dishes on the menu (I don't care if it is the loin) parading as real crab meat while they are processed pollock.
author: jen h.

description: Excellent breakfast with good enough portions. Not too much and not too little. Pricings are not too bad also. Had the Chorizo Scramble, was good. Friend had California Sandwich and was tasty. They also have freshly squeezed orange juice.
author: Thomas C.

description: Very good food, at very reasonable price, the line to order seems too long but it moved fast. The servers are very courteous. They are opened until evening however we only tried breakfast, but their whole menu looks delicious
author: Henry D.

description:
What a fun name! My partner in crime and I decided to come here because it was right down the street from our hotel and we love a good breakfast place.  We ended up ordering the Florentine Crepe (spinach, cheddar, and cottage cheese), the Eggs Benedict, the Blintz (dessert crepe).

The interior was charming with an easy to read menu written on the wall.  The flavored water was refreshing (orange or cucumber, basil, and lemon). The portion sizes were generous, which also included a side for each order.  The system seemed pretty straight forward - order at the register, take a number to table, and the food is delivered 10-15 minutes later.    

The poached eggs were cooked as requested - yes, they ask for easy, medium, or hard! - but the potatoes were overly seasoned with rosemary (something I personally pair with a roast chicken dinner and not breakfast food).  The biggest dissapointment though was the crepe - it was good, just nothing special!  Perhaps I should have ordered something with sausage or ham in it in, because the spinach combination lacked umpf (maybe some mushrooms in to make it "meaty"?) The crepes themselves were much thicker than I expected - literally a thin IHOP pancake and not a more delicate crepe, although I suppose its thickness was deliberate in order to stand up to the filling, which was generous. Suggestion: Two traditionally thin crepes with filling instead of one thick crepe with lots of filling.  My partner and I also ordered the Blintz (strawberry and marmalade dessert crepe) and we were told it would come out 10 minutes after our "entrees".  Cool, but after a few bites of our entrees, we requested to cancel the Blintz because, truly, there was so much food! Our request was denied because "they were already making the Blintz."  Really? You can't scrap a crepe? Can't prepare it for the next person's order? It's a spoonful of batter on a griddle! (I assume, anyways)  I'm not asking to cancel a 20 minute made-to-order soufflé or a well done steak. Grudgingly, we accepted the to-go box with the crepe and took it with us to the airport.  Needless to say, when stomach space allowed me to dig in, it was a big soggy mess - once again, those thick crepes! In the trash it went. How disappointing.  

In summary - Cute, but for those who value quality over quantity, look elsewhere.
author: Angela N.

description: Big menu, located on a corner near union square. Great for breakfast and lunch. Try the North Beach Crepe! Yummmy!!! I usually hate crepes with food but this one was with lots of flavors. Will come back and try other plates in the menu. U order at the counter and they give u a number to place in your table. Floors seemed a bit dirty, maybe from lunch rush.
author: favio p.

description: This place was okay for a quick weekday breakfast. I had a basic breakfast, which consisted of scrambled eggs, wheat toast, potatoes, and bacon. It was good, nothing that blew my mind. The potatoes had rosemary in them, which made them stand out from the ordinary breakfast potatoes, they were tasty. My friend and I shared a banana and nutella crepe, which of course was quite tasty!! My only complaint about this place is that it was SUPER hot inside, so hot that I was very uncomfortable eating my breakfast. Customer service was good.
author: Mandi C.

description:
Service - 3
Atmosphere - 6
Food - 8
Vegetarian Friendly - 8
General Awesomeness - 7

Good food overshadowed by a staff that would prefer that customers go ahead and stay home.
author: Buford M.

description:
Delicious savory crepes, both entree and dessert. The extensive menu offers a plethora of food choices to fill your belly from crepes to pastas to soups and salads to burgers and then some.

Quaint, pleasant atmosphere on off-peak hours, save for the background music which went from holiday mixes one day to Indian and then bad top 40 club hits the next day. This, however, does not detract from the feel, but rather provides an interesting conversation piece.

All in all, my new favorite eatery.
author: Kim L.

description: Great place to have breakfast, it gets busy so plan well. Staff is friendly, service was good, not much interaction but I can't be mad since they are extremely busy.
author: Edith G.

description:
This spot is a GREAT neighborhood find.I do know that it was vacant
for at least 10 years before it became HH and finally,another
breakfast option in the 'hood!! I'm not a big crepe person,but I
have tried the french toast,and I'm sold! Thick and fluffy and 
sizzled to perfection..and that syrup.....mmmm so good.

Pros-Ideal location,spacious,nice dim lightning and friendly
cashier.

XO
author: Gia X.

description:
Not too far off of Union Square is a cute place to get a decent breakfast.  The prices are reasonable and the staff is really nice.  

French Toast, Apple Chicken Sausage, Roasted Potatoes and Fresh Fruit.  The food was decent.  Maybe I needed to try their crepes.  So what were my issues?  First, I prefer sausage links, which they served flattened like a patty.  Second, my french toast wasn't crispy on the outside.  Hmmm, that's all I have to say.
author: Minna T.

description: The concierge at my hotel recommended them as a good spot for lunch, and I decided on the warm chicken salad and wasn't disappointed.  The salad had plenty of cherry tomato halves, mushrooms, sun dried tomatoes and hot green onion stems to go with the base of romaine lettuce, topped generously with spicy chicken breast chunks.  Service is sparse, and the guy who took my order and delivered my meal was unfriendly, despite my attempt to tip him in person at the end of the meal.  Pretty immature.  The selection of drinks is okay, but not impressive.  The atmosphere is very casual and relaxed.  Overall a good experience, and I can't wait until the next time I'm there to try their crepes and breakfast fare.
author: Tim L.

description: Nice spot, free WiFi, nice staff. Extensive selection, ok prices. I had 1/2 tuna sandwich and black bean chilli. The tuna was not mediocre as wes the soup. I want to try breakfast though it looked tasty.
author: Marina M.

description: Ordered from the Breakfast Special at 915pm and ordered 3 buttermilk pancakes. You can add fruit for $1.75 more! The pancakes were seriously amazing. The texture was fluffy with a bit of chewiness added with excellent flavor! The service was super friendly and FAST! The restaurant was pretty busy even late at night. I do think the ambiance could be more cafe style; seemed to have mixed decor themes. Maybe keep simple yellow walls vs all patterns. Loved the chalk menu, easy to read (large print).
author: Heather A.

description: Came for lunch, had excellent savory crepes.  The filling was well chosen, the crepes themselves were tasty and light, not soggy.  Free refills on the iced coffee.  Left full, caffeinated, and happy.
author: Samuel F.

description: Sooooo good! I got the pesto chicken crepe and there was so much chicken! Delicious!
author: Matt G.

description: Normally I get breakfast At this cafe when staying in SFO since it's near the hotel I stay at. The only thing I can write is that portion sizes have decreased big time, my plate used to have big generous heapings, but this time it was just 'ok' and a tad on the 'still hungry side'.  Kinda pricy too
author: Carl I.

description: Dessert crepes were too sweet and saucy. Savory crepes were loaded with too much cheese. Music was one notch too loud. The long line of people waiting to order on our visit because the cashier was also the barista, which slowed things down considerably. And, fwiw, the decor was reminiscent of a Mexican restaurant. Yes, this place is in the middle of tourist central, but tourists to SF should reasonably expect passable crepes.
author: B Q.

description: Although I am not a resident of SF, I am a frequent visitor.  As this place is nestled amongst hotels, it is a little touristy.  It is a great place if you are looking for a decent quick bite for breakfast.  The selection of crepes is unique and expansive.  I have been here twice and been satisfied both times but never blown away by deliciousness.  I recommend the crepe with the hollandaise sauce...but then again I could eat that sauce all day long.
author: Liz B.

description:
Great brunch, especially for the price. Salmon benedict, banana and nutella crepes, huevos rancheros, fruit bowl and two coffees - $40. All were good - though the huevos rancheros was a bit on the "wet" side.

It's close to a bunch of backpackers, so the place has a youngish, slightly hung over vibe to it :) The interior ain't going to win any design awards but the food is good and plentiful and fast.
author: James A.

description: Had fresh squeezed OJ, eggs, bacon and a bagel - was good. Saw neighbors eating a stack of pancakes as wide as his head and Nutella crepes. Looked awesome!!
author: Ursula J.

description: Really good. Awesome portions and prices. Santa fe dish was bomb. When i was there it wasnt busy at all and we got our food fast.
author: Patrick J.

description:
